3. Personal service, notice by certified mail, and notice by publication are not required for violations of subsection 4-4-2A, "Weeds", of this chapter.
Service of a notice to abate for violations of subsection 4-4-2A of this chapter shall be accomplished by posting the notice in a conspicuous place on
the property or building where the violation has occurred and sending the notice by regular mail to the owner and/or responsible party of the property.
If there is no building on the property, a sign shall be posted on the property providing notice. The owner and/or responsible party must comply with
the notice and abate the violation within seventy two (72) hours from the date of posting and mailing. (Ord. 1977, 3-4-2013)
4-4-5: ABATEMENT BY ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDINGS:
A. Content Of Notice: In the event the Enforcement Officer decides to abate a nuisance administratively, the notice to abate shall include the following
information:
1. Description of what constitutes a nuisance, citing the appropriate Code section.
2. Description of the action necessary to abate the nuisance.
3. The order to abate within a specified time period.
4. The notice shall advise that, upon failure to comply with the order to abate, the City shall undertake such abatement and that the cost of abatement
may be assessed against the property for collection in the same manner as Property Taxes.
5. The notice shall also advise as to the opportunity for an administrative hearing and that failure to request such a hearing within the time specified in
the notice shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing and that said notice shall thereafter become a final determination and order to abate.
6. Fees for the administrative hearing shall be ten dollars ($10.00). (Ord. 1009, 6-22-1992)
B. Administrative Hearing: The hearing shall be held before the Municipal code hearing officer, and shall be in accordance with the procedures of section
4-4-9 of this chapter, except as herein otherwise provided. The determination and order shall be appealable to the city council or the county district
court by writ of certiorari. The order shall not be carried out until the time for filing the writ of certiorari has expired. (Ord. 1009, 6-22-1992; amd. Ord.
1542, 9-2-2003)
4-4-6: ABATEMENT BY MUNICIPAL INFRACTION PROCEEDINGS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 239/687
A. Content Of Notice: In the event the enforcement officer decides to abate a nuisance through the municipal infraction process, the notice to abate shall
include the following information:
1. Description of what constitutes a nuisance, citing the appropriate code section.
2. Description of the action necessary to abate the nuisance.
3. The order to abate within a specified time period.
4. Explanation that failure to abate the nuisance within the time specified will result in the issuance of a civil citation charging the owner or responsible
party with a municipal infraction.
5. Explanation that each day that a nuisance is permitted to continue constitutes a separate offense.
6. Explanation that upon being found guilty of a municipal infraction, the court is authorized to order abatement, assess the costs of abatement against
the property and/or enter them as a judgment against the defendant, and assess a civil penalty against the defendant.
B. Issuance Of Civil Citation: In the event that the nuisance is not abated as ordered and within the time specified in the notice to abate, the enforcement
officer may issue a civil citation to the property owner or responsible party, charging that person with a municipal infraction. The enforcement officer
may, but shall not be required to, give notice to abate prior to issuance of a civil citation for a repeat offense involving the same property and occurring
within one year of a prior violation. (Ord. 1009, 6-22-1992)
4-4-7: ABATEMENT REMEDIES; PENALTIES:
A. Abatement may include, but shall not be limited to, repair, removal, cleaning, extermination, cutting, mowing, grading, sewer repairs, draining, securing,
repairing a building or structure, boarding unoccupied buildings, barricading or fencing, removing dangerous portions of buildings or structures and
demolition of dangerous structures or abandoned buildings.
B. The cost of abatement may be assessed against the property for collection in the same manner as property taxes. Abatement costs shall include the
cost of removing or eliminating the nuisance, the cost of investigation, such as title searches, inspection and testing; the cost of notification; filing costs;
and other related administrative costs. Inoperable and/or obsolete vehicles which have been impounded may be sold in accordance with state law. If an
inoperable and/or obsolete vehicle is not sold or if the proceeds of such sale or redemption are not sufficient for payment of the cost of abatement,
storage and sale of said inoperable and/or obsolete vehicle, such cost or the balance of such cost may be assessed against the property for collection
in the same manner as a property tax.
C. In a municipal infraction proceeding for the abatement of a nuisance, the court may order any one or more of the following:
1. Place a judgment against the person and/or property of the defendant for the costs of abatement.
2. Levy a civil penalty (fine) against the defendant as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
3. Order abatement of the nuisance in any manner as provided in this chapter.
4. Assess costs of abatement against the property for collection in the same manner as property taxes. (Ord. 1734, 3-12-2007)
4-4-8: EMERGENCY ABATEMENT PROCEDURE:
When the enforcement officer determines that a nuisance exists on a property and the nuisance constitutes an imminent clear and compelling danger to
health, safety or welfare of persons or property, the enforcement officer is authorized to abate or have abated the nuisance without prior notice and
opportunity of hearing. The costs of such action may be assessed against the property for collection in the same manner as property tax. However, prior to
such assessment, the city shall give a property owner notice by certified mail and the opportunity for an administrative hearing in accordance with the
procedures of section 4-4-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 1009, 6-22-1992)
4-4-9: MUNICIPAL CODE HEARING OFFICER:
A. Purpose: A hearing officer, designated by the mayor and subject to city council approval, shall hold administrative hearings concerning abatement of
nuisances in the administrative process.
B. Procedures: All proceedings shall be in accordance with the requirements of this section.
C. Hearing On Actions, Interpretations, Notices And Orders:
1. Any person affected by any action, interpretation, notice or order which has been issued by a code enforcement officer in connection with the
enforcement of this chapter, through the administrative abatement process, may request, and shall be granted, a hearing on the matter before the
municipal code hearing officer; provided, that, such a request for a hearing must be in a form of a written petition and must be filed with the city clerk
within the following time periods: a) where a notice or order was served or mailed pursuant to this chapter, written petition must be filed with the city
clerk within seven (7) calendar days; b) where notice or order was published as provided in this chapter, written petition must be filed with the city
clerk within seven (7) calendar days after date of last publication; c) where a notice or order was served by posting in a conspicuous place on the
property or building deemed a nuisance, a written petition must be filed with the clerk within seven (7) calendar days of the posting of the notice. Any
petition so filed shall state the particular section of the ordinance involved and a brief statement of grounds upon which such appeal is taken. Failure
to request a hearing and filing a timely petition as prescribed herein shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing, and the notice or order shall
become a final determination and order.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 240/687
2. Upon receipt of a timely filed petition, the hearing officer shall set a time and place for such hearing and shall give written notification thereof.
Notification shall be given either through personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice shall include a statement of the
time, place and nature of the hearing.
3. If the petitioner fails to appear at such hearing, the hearing officer may proceed with the hearing and make a decision in the absence of the party.
D. Time For Commencement Of Hearing: The hearing shall be commenced not later than twenty (20) days after the date on which the petition was filed;
however, this time may be extended for a reasonable period by the presiding officer.
E. Hearing Procedure:
1. The hearing shall be open to the public and shall be recorded either by mechanical means or by manual means. Opportunity shall be afforded all
parties to respond and present evidence and argument on all issues involved. Parties may represent themselves or may be represented by legal
counsel.
2. Irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded. A finding shall be based upon the kind of evidence on which reasonably
prudent persons are accustomed to rely for the conduct of their serious affairs, and may be based upon such evidence even if it would be
inadmissible in a court of law. The hearing officer shall give effect to the rules of privilege recognized by law. Objections to evidentiary offers may be
made and shall be noted in the record. Subject to these requirements, when a hearing will be expedited and the interests of the parties will not be
prejudiced substantially, any part of the evidence may be required to be submitted in verified written form.
3. Documentary evidence may be received in the form of copies or excerpts, if the original is not readily available. Upon request, parties shall be given
an opportunity to compare the copy with the original, if available.
4. Witnesses at the hearing, or available persons whose testimony has been submitted in written form, shall be subject to cross examination by any
party as necessary for a full and true disclosure of the facts.
5. The hearing officer's experience, technical competence, and specialized knowledge may be utilized in the evaluation of the evidence.
6. The hearing officer shall conduct the hearing and have power to administer oaths. The hearing officer may cause subpoenas to be issued for such a
witnesses and the production of such books and papers as either party may designate. The subpoenas may be signed by the hearing officer.
7. An appeal pursuant to this chapter shall not stay the effect of a notice or order under the emergency provisions of this chapter unless so ordered by
the hearing officer.
F. Decision Of Hearing Officer After Hearing: Upon submission of all evidence and at the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall render a
decision based upon the record. This decision may be made immediately after the conclusion of the hearing or within a reasonable time thereafter. The
hearing officer may affirm, modify or reverse any action, interpretation, notice or order which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of an
ordinance. A decision shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law separately stated. Following the decision of the hearing officer, all parties
shall be notified of the decision by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. Any party to the hearing, including the city, may seek
judicial review by filing a petition in the county district court within twenty (20) days after the issuance of the decision by the hearing officer. Before filing
a petition for judicial review in the district court, the affected party may appeal the decision of the hearing officer to the city council. This appeal shall be
filed within forty eight (48) hours of the decision being rendered and notice of such appeal shall be filed with the city clerk. The city council shall review
the proceedings based upon the record made before the hearing officer and may, with city council's consent, grant to each affected party an
opportunity to appear and present arguments to the city council on the relief sought. The city council may affirm, modify or reverse the hearing officer's
decision. Judicial review by the county district court shall be filed within twenty (20) days from the date of the city council decision.
G. Emergency Orders: Notwithstanding any provision stated in this chapter, whenever in the judgment of the municipal officer, agent or employee, an
emergency exists creating a dangerous and imminent health or safety hazard to persons, property or the general public which requires immediate
action, he/she shall order such action as may be necessary to meet the emergency. Any orders issued pursuant to this section shall be effective
immediately or in the time and manner prescribed in the order itself.
H. Authority Of City To Perform Work Upon Failure Of Property Owner: Should any property owner affected by any notice or order issued pursuant to this
chapter fail to perform an action required by said notice or order, the city, where otherwise allowed by law, may perform the required action and assess
the costs against the property involved. (Ord. 1542, 9-2-2003)
4-4-10: SPECIFIED CRIME PROPERTY; DECLARATION AND ABATEMENT:
A. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:
BOOTLEGGING: The illegal sale or service of alcoholic liquor, wine, or beer in violation of Iowa Code (2005), chapter 123.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The person who has the responsibility to supervise and direct the police department or his or her designee.
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: A drug, substance or immediate precursor as defined by Iowa Code (2005) chapter 124.
DISORDERLY CONDUCT: Two (2) or more separate incidents on separate dates within a twelve (12) month period which involved an act defined as
disorderly conduct under Iowa Code (2005) section 723.4(1), (2) or (3).
GAMBLING: Games of skill or chance as defined by Iowa Code (2005) chapter 99B and prohibited by Iowa Code (2005) section 725.
OWNER: Any person, agent, firm, corporation, association, or a partnership,including a mortgagee in possession, in whom is vested all or part of the
legal title to property or all or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to present use and enjoyment of the premises.
PERSON: Any natural person, association, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity capable of owning or using property.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 241/687
PROSTITUTION, PIMPING, AND PANDERING: Those acts or activities as defined by Iowa Code (2005) chapter 725.
SPECIFIED CRIME PROPERTY: Any structure, including the real property upon which it is situated, in which activity involving the unauthorized
delivery, possession or manufacture of a controlled substance, illegal gambling, bootlegging, prostitution, pimping or pandering, or disorderly conduct is
occurring.
STRUCTURE: Any building or structure, including, but not limited to, edifice, units, or any portion thereof, and the real property upon which such
building or structure is situated.
B. No person shall use or allow to be used any structure as specified crime property. When the structure and the property upon which it is situated are
owned by different persons, each person shall not use or allow to be used such structure and property as specified crime property.
C. Any person who fails to perform an act required by this section or who commits an act prohibited by this section shall be guilty of a municipal infraction
punishable by a civil penalty as provided by section 1-4-1 of this code.
D. When the chief of police or his or her designee has a reasonable belief that a structure is being used or maintained in violation of this section, the chief
of police may notify the owner of record in writing that the structure has been declared to be a specified crime property.
A reasonable belief that a structure is being used as specified crime property may be found from, but is not limited to, evidence of drug paraphernalia in
or around the structure; an increase in vehicular or pedestrian traffic in or around the structure; observations of the exchange of money; verified citizen
complaints of bootlegging; unauthorized delivery or manufacture of a controlled substance; illegal gambling, bootlegging, prostitution, pimping or
pandering, disorderly conduct; and any other activity which leads a police officer to reasonably believe violations exist.
E. The notice required in subsection D of this section shall notify the owner of record in writing that a structure owned by him or her has been declared to
be a specified crime property, and such notice shall contain the following information:
1. The street address and a description sufficient for identification of the premises on which the structure is located; and
2. A statement that the chief of police has found the structure to be in violation of this section, with an explanation as to why the structure has been
declared a specified crime property.
F. A copy of the notice given pursuant to this section shall be served on the owner or an agent at least twenty (20) days prior to the commencement of any
judicial action by the city. Service shall be made either personally or by mailing a copy of the notice to the owner or owner's registered agent of the
notice by registered or certified mail. In the event that notice is impossible to be served as set out above, a copy of the notice may be posted at the
property if ten (10) days have elapsed from the service or mailing of the notice to the owner and no response or reply has been received by the city
from the owner during that period of time.
The failure of any owner to receive actual notice of the determination of the chief of police shall not preclude future proceedings under this section.
G. Upon receipt of a notice of specified crime property as set out herein the owner of record may challenge such notice by filing a request for an
administrative hearing. Such request shall be in writing and filed with the city clerk or his or her designee within ten (10) days of the service of the
notice of specified crime property.
1. Failure to request a hearing within such time period or to attend a scheduled hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to such a hearing.
2. Upon filing of a request for an administrative hearing, further judicial action pursuant to this section shall be stayed pending the outcome of the
administrative hearing.
H. The hearing held pursuant to this section shall be conducted before the municipal code hearing officer as provided in section 4-4-9 of this chapter within
a reasonable period of time. Such hearing may be continued for good cause. A notice of hearing, including the time, date and location of the hearing,
shall be made by mailing a copy of the notice by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the owner of record or his or her registered agent.
I. The sole issue before the hearing officer shall be whether there exists a reasonable belief that the structure was being used as specified crime property
when the declaration of specified crime property was made pursuant to this section. The hearing officer shall decide only that either: 1) there is a
reasonable belief that the structure was used as specified crime property and that the provisions of this section shall apply, or 2) there is not a sufficient
reasonable belief that the structure was being used as specified crime property and that the procedures of this section shall be permanently stayed. A
finding of no reasonable belief however shall not preclude a future independent complaint, investigation and notice of specified crime property. The
hearing officer shall issue a written finding which shall be mailed to the owner or his or her registered agent.
J. Subsequent to the declaration and notice that there exists a specified crime property, an owner shall have the opportunity to abate the illegal activity
within ten (10) days. If a landlord/tenant relationship exists on the specified crime property, the owner/landlord may be deemed to have abated the
activity upon demonstration that he or she has taken legal action as allowed by Iowa Code chapter 562A to terminate the rental agreement and
continues in good faith to follow abatement procedures and provides the chief of police with copies of all notices served in accordance with Iowa Code
chapter 562A.
K. If after twenty (20) days the chief of police determines that a specified crime property has not been abated, a notice of fine and an order of abatement
shall be filed in compliance with Iowa Code section 364.22, and the chief of police shall notify the chief building official of the failure to abate.
L. In addition to the provisions of subsection K of this section, the chief building official may revoke, refuse to renew or deny a pending application for a
rental certificate for a specified crime property that has not been abated within twenty (20) days by written notice to the owner or owner's agent by
regular mail sent to the owner's or owner's agent's address as provided on the rental certificate application. Said revocation shall take effect twenty (20)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 242/687
days after the date the notice is mailed. The owner may appeal the revocation to the municipal code hearing officer as provided by subsections 4-4-9E,
F and G of this chapter by filing a written request for hearing with the city clerk prior to the date the revocation takes effect. The burden to prove that
abatement has occurred shall be on the property owner by a preponderance of the evidence. If no such appeal is taken, or if the municipal hearing
officer finds during said appeal that the specified crime property has not been abated, then the rental permit shall be revoked and reapplication shall
not be considered until such property is abated. The hearing officer may provide in the appeal corrective action that must occur before the property
shall be abated. (Ord. 1634, 5-23-2005)
Chapter 5
SOLID WASTE CONTROL
4-5-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a sanitary method for the collection and disposal of all solid waste and to safeguard the citizens from hazards to
their health, safety and welfare, that result from the uncontrolled collection and disposal of solid waste. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The City Manager, or his delegated representative, shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-3: DEFINITIONS:
For use in this chapter, unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms are defined:
AGENCY: The Metro Waste Authority.
BANNED SUBSTANCE OR HAZARDOUS WASTE: Any waste prohibited by the Iowa Code, Metro Waste Authority and/or applicable Federal regulations
from being disposed in sanitary landfills, including yard waste, lead acid batteries, waste oil, explosive material, medical waste, drugs, poisons, soil
dressings, highly combustible material and hazardous substance.
BULKY ITEM: Any solid waste item that does not fit in a City approved cart.
CITY APPROVED CART: A container approved by the City for the collection of solid waste.
CITY APPROVED YARD WASTE BAG: A "yard waste bag", as defined herein, which is approved by the City for the purpose of a yard waste collection
program.
CITY APPROVED YARD WASTE STICKER: A self-adhesive sticker cost controlled by the City for the purpose of affixing to an approved yard waste bag,
and affixing to bundles of tree or brush debris for regular collection and disposal.
COMPOSTING: A controlled microbiologic degradation of organic waste to produce a relatively nuisance free product of potential value as a soil
conditioner.
DISPOSAL SITE: A sanitary landfill, transfer station, compost site or other facility for receiving or disposing of solid waste, yard waste or tree debris of any
size.
LAWN REFUSE: Grass clippings, leaves, garden wastes, prunings and weeds.
LEAD ACID BATTERIES: Those batteries falling within the definition of "hazardous substance" as defined by the Iowa Code.
MEDICAL WASTE: That waste defined as "medical waste" by the Iowa Department of Natural Resources.
METRO WASTE AUTHORITY YARD WASTE BAG: A "yard waste bag", as defined herein, which is manufactured for, distributed for, and cost controlled
by the Metro Waste Authority for the purpose of a regional yard waste collection program.
METRO WASTE AUTHORITY YARD WASTE STICKER: A self-adhesive sticker manufactured for, distributed for, and cost controlled by the Metro Waste
Authority for the purpose of affixing to an approved yard waste bag, other than the Metro Waste Authority yard waste bag, and affixing to bundles of tree or
brush debris for regular collection and disposal.
OWNER: Whenever used in this chapter, the word "owner" shall, in addition to the record titleholder, include any person residing in, renting, leasing or
occupying residential premises or operating or transacting business in any premises, and as between such parties with duties, responsibilities, liabilities
and obligations hereinafter imposed shall be joint and several.
PERSON: Means and includes an individual or group or association of individuals; a firm or any member thereof; a corporation, or any executive officer,
manager, person in charge, or employee thereof; and the use of a pronoun specifying the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter gender.
REGULAR COLLECTION: Regular collection is conducted once weekly on the same day as regular solid waste collection day.
RESIDENTIAL PREMISES: Means and includes detached single-family dwellings and any multiple-family attached dwellings up to and including four (4)
separate family quarters.
RUBBLE: Dirt, stone, brick or similar inorganic material or street sweepings.
SOLID WASTE: The waste generated by normal residential activity, excluding yard waste, bulky waste and all specialized collections. Solid waste does not
include dirt, sod, stone, brick, construction materials, or hazardous waste as defined in section 455B.411 of the Code of Iowa, or source, special nuclear,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 243/687
or byproduct material as defined in the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended to January 1, 1979.
SPECIAL COLLECTION: Special collection is offered by special arrangement with the City approved contractor.
TREE DEBRIS: Organic debris such as tree branches, limbs and trunks of six inches (6") or less in diameter. Tree debris shall not include tree branches,
limbs or trunks greater than six inches (6") in diameter nor tree stumps of any size.
WASTE OIL: Any petroleum based or synthetic oil which, through its use, storage or handling, has become unsuitable for its original purpose due to the
presence of chemical or physical impurities.
YARD WASTE: Organic debris such as grass clippings, leaves, garden wastes, prunings, weeds, brush and tree branches produced as a part of the yard
and garden development and maintenance. "Yard waste" does not include tree stumps or branches greater than ten inches (10") in diameter.
YARD WASTE BAG: 2-ply, fifty (50) pound wet strength kraft type paper bags which are degradable or biodegradable, with a maximum capacity of thirty
(30) gallons, manufactured for the purpose of containing yard waste for regular collection and disposal and which display a printed statement designating
that the bag is intended to hold yard waste.
YARD WASTE COLLECTION HAULER: Any person who comes into the possession or control of yard waste by reason of the operation of a disposition
service of collection, hauling and/or disposal. (Ord. 1369, 6-14-1999, eff. 7-5-1999; amd. Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000; Ord. 1973, 1-21-2013)
4-5-4: COLLECTION OF SOLID WASTE:
The owner or occupant of each premises in the City shall regularly remove or arrange for the regular removal of solid waste from premises under their
direct or indirect control for safe disposal in a manner consistent with the provisions of this chapter. Any yard waste to be removed from the site on which it
has developed for disposal on another site shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all other solid waste accumulated on the premises. Any
banned substances shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all other solid waste accumulated on the premises. No person shall deposit in a
solid waste container or otherwise offer any banned substances for collection with other solid waste in any manner which may result in improper disposal
of a banned substance.
The City will provide to each residential premises solid waste collection service as defined in this chapter for the removal and disposal of yard waste and
other solid waste; provided, however, that the owner or occupant of each such premises shall separately remove or arrange for the removal and proper
disposal of banned substances and of vehicles and any other solid waste limited or excluded from the service provided by the City. The residential
premises collection service of the City is subject to the following conditions:
A. Frequency: Such collections shall be made on a weekly basis except at times during emergency periods or during a specific holiday in accordance with
schedules to be developed by the City Manager.
B. Schedule Adjusted: The City Manager is authorized and empowered to change or amend such schedules from time to time as he, in his discretion, shall
deem necessary. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
C. Street Collection: Collection of solid waste shall only be made from a public street; alley collection is prohibited. An exception may be granted by the
City Council to permit collection on a private street or private drive if the owner(s) of the private street(s) and/or private drive(s) provide an agreement to
indemnify and hold harmless the City, the Metro Waste Authority, and the waste hauler(s) for any and all liability, damages, claims, costs, expenses,
interest, and reasonable attorney fees for any damage that may occur to their private streets and drives relating to or arising out of the collection of
solid waste. The City Council may further grant an exception to collect solid waste for any horizontally attached multiple-family dwellings comprising
more than four (4) separate family quarters provided that each dwelling have a separate driveway to each unit and each unit is either on its own
separate lot or is part of a residential horizontal property regime. This exception does not include stacked multi-family dwellings. (Ord. 1973, 1-21-2013)
D. Placement Of Carts:
1. Streets: Whenever solid waste is collected adjoining the street curb or street right-of-way, residents desiring to have solid waste collected by the City
in accordance with this chapter shall place their carts upon the driveway, parking or right-of-way in front of their premises, adjacent to, and within
eighteen inches (18") of the near edge of the roadway curb or adjacent to and within eighteen inches (18") from the edge of the traveled portion of
the right-of-way. Placement of carts shall not obstruct sidewalks, and shall not be placed closer than six feet (6') of any fixed structure. Exceptions to
cart placement may be granted by the City Contract Administrator based upon rules adopted by the City. The City approved contractor may calculate
regular fees and any special fee required for other than curbside collection, subject to the approval of the City Contract Administrator. (Ord. 1428, 11-
27-2000)
2. Obstruction To Trafficways: No solid waste or solid waste carts shall be deposited by any person upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, roadway or upon
any alley right-of-way, so as to obstruct or block pedestrian movement or vehicular traffic. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991; amd. Ord. 1428, 11-
27-2000)
E. Number Of Carts And Type At Curb: The total number of carts excluding lawn refuse bags to be collected by the City from residential premises per
week shall not exceed the number of City approved carts made available by the City to each residence. Solid waste shall be placed in the City
approved cart in disposable bags, boxes or tied or taped together so individual items will not blow or scatter when the cart is emptied. Bulky items
and/or additional solid waste bags shall be placed outside the City approved cart and shall require a City approved sticker for collection.
F. Carts, Bundles, Recycling Bins, Pieces Of Yard Waste And Other Items Offered For Collection: Carts, bundles, recycling bins, pieces of tree debris and
yard waste and other items offered for residential collection shall be placed at the curb or back of the traveled portion of the right-of-way and shall be
separated by a distance of three feet (3'), but not more than six feet (6'). (Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
G. Residential Yard Waste And Tree Debris:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 244/687
1. The amount of residential yard waste in approved yard waste bags and bundles of tree debris placed for regular residential collection by the City or a
contracted hauler shall not be limited.
2. Tree debris, branches, trunks and stumps resulting from the removal of trees by a tree service contractor shall not be placed for collection by the
City, but shall be removed by a licensed hauler at the expense of the owner or tree service.
3. All yard waste and tree debris shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all other solid waste at the time of regular collection and disposal.
(Ord. 1369, 6-14-1999, eff. 7-5-1999)
4. All yard waste must be in an approved yard waste bag with a City approved yard waste sticker affixed to the yard waste bag.
5. Tree debris and brush under six inches (6") in diameter, prepared for regular collection and disposal by the City approved contractor, shall be
securely tied in bundles not larger than forty eight inches (48") long and eighteen inches (18") in diameter, and the bundle shall have a City approved
waste sticker affixed to it. If there is insufficient quantity to securely bundle, all tree debris and brush shall be cut down and placed in an approved
yard waste bag with an affixed City approved yard waste sticker. No loose tree debris will be picked up. Pieces of tree branches greater than six
inches (6") in diameter shall not be included in a bundle but shall be disposed by special collection arrangements with a private hauler.
6. No bag of yard waste, bundle of tree debris or piece of tree branch greater than six inches (6") in diameter offered for regular or yard waste collection
shall weigh more than fifty (50) pounds.
H. Time Of Placing Carts, Bundles, Recycling Bins, Pieces Of Yard Waste, Lawn Refuse Bags And Other Items At Curb: On street pick-up routes no solid
waste in any form or in any type of container or any other item offered for collection shall be placed at the curb or behind the traveled portion of the
right-of-way for collection before five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of the day preceding the day such waste is scheduled by the City to be collected, and all carts
and items not collected shall be removed from the curb or from behind the traveled portion of the right-of-way within twenty four (24) hours of collection.
(Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
I. Failure To Comply: Any failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall relieve the City of obligation to collect such solid waste therefrom which
is not in compliance therewith as to type, preparation, volume or place of storage, but in all cases such solid waste from such premises as meets the
requirements of such sections shall be collected as herein provided.
J. Prohibition Of The Collection Of Banned Materials:
1. All Municipal waste picked up within the corporate limits of the City shall not contain banned substances. All banned substances shall be separated
by the owner or occupant from all other Municipal solid waste accumulated on the premises.
2. Any individual, corporation or licensed hauler for the transport of waste to the landfill shall not haul banned substances to the landfill. All banned
substances must be separated by the hauler from all other normal solid waste before transportation of waste to the landfill. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990,
eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-5: LICENSE TO HAUL SOLID WASTE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2289, 4-2-2018)
4-5-6: DISPOSAL SITE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permitted Disposal Sites: No person shall haul or cause to be hauled any solid waste material, other than those resulting from construction or
demolition activities, to any disposal place or site or area other than the following:
1. Agency Site: A sanitary disposal site operated by or under contract to the Des Moines Metropolitan Area Solid Waste Agency; or
2. Transfer Station: A solid waste transfer station licensed and operating pursuant to the provisions of article B of this chapter.
B. Solid Waste Disposal Sites: No person shall operate or permit the operation on his property, of a disposal site in the City for the disposal of solid waste
of any kind, and rubble from any source other than construction or demolition activities. (Ord. 2289, 4-2-2018)
4-5-7: TREATMENT PENDING COLLECTION:
All solid waste consisting of dry animal waste and vegetable matter, which may attract flies, dogs, rodents, or other animals or insects, shall be drained of
all excess liquid, wrapped in paper or disposable containers and placed or stored, until collected, in covered suitable containers as described in section 4-
5-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991; amd. Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
4-5-8: ACCUMULATIONS OF SOLID WASTE:
A. Accumulations Hazardous To Health: No person shall permit accumulations on any premises, improved or vacant, or in any public place, quantities of
solid waste, either in containers or not, that shall constitute a health or sanitation hazard.
B. Accumulations Hazardous To Property: No person shall permit to accumulate quantities of solid waste, within or close to any building, unless the same
is stored in containers in such a manner as not to create a health or fire hazard. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-9: CONTAINER SPECIFICATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 245/687
A. Carts: Unless otherwise noted, disposal of solid waste for collection by the City approved contractor shall only be made in City approved carts.
B. Disposal Bags: Disposable bags manufactured for solid waste disposal shall be acceptable for bulky items. Disposable bags and contents shall not
exceed fifty (50) pounds. (Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
C. Composting Lawn Refuse:
1. The owner or occupant is encouraged to compost lawn refuse on the premises where it is developed; provided, that the material accumulated for
such purpose is restricted to the rear yard of the property and is properly contained and processed without creating offensive odors, litter, fire or
vector problems. Such composting shall be deemed to be an acceptable alternative disposal of lawn refuse which satisfies requirements in this
chapter to separate lawn refuse for collection and disposal. Material accumulated or used for composting on such premises shall not include any
kitchen or food wastes.
2. Nothing in this chapter is intended to prevent the owner from transporting yard waste accumulating on premises of the owner, provided such yard
waste is disposed of at City approved composting stations in accordance with policies established by the composting station. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990,
eff. 1-1-1991; amd. Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
D. Nonconforming Containers: Baskets, boxes and noncomplying solid waste containers shall be considered disposable refuse and shall be removed by
the collection crews if they are the proper size and otherwise acceptable for collection with a City approved sticker; or shall be left uncollected if they
are larger than the allowable size or unacceptable for collection. (Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
4-5-10: COLLECTION AND HAULING OF WASTE:
A. Protection Of Hauling Vehicles: No person shall haul any solid waste or yard waste or banned substances upon the streets, alleys or public places of
the City in any manner except in a vehicle or container so equipped as to prevent the blowing or leakage or dropping off of any of the contents on the
public streets or ways of the City or private property therein.
B. Loading Collection Vehicles Or Containers: Vehicles or containers used for the collection and transportation of any solid waste shall be loaded and
moved in such a manner that the contents will not fall, leak or spill therefrom, and shall be covered to prevent blowing or loss of material. Where
spillage does occur, the material shall be picked up immediately by the collector or transporter and returned to the vehicle or container and the area
properly cleaned. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-11: LITTERING:
Resident owner shall be responsible for complying with all provisions herein to prevent littering. (Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
4-5-12: DISPOSITION OF WASTE TO CONTROLLED SITE; NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2289, 4-2-2018)
4-5-13: MATERIALS EXCLUDED FROM AGENCY DEPOSIT SITES:
At the discretion of the agency, certain materials may be excluded from those solid wastes which may be deposited at an agency landfill site. These
excluded materials may include junk automobile bodies and similar bulky objects, which may require special processing prior to disposal, trees and tree
limbs, unless they have been cut into pieces not exceeding four feet (4') in length, burning materials or materials containing hot or live coals, hazardous
materials, banned materials, and other materials which the agency deems necessary to exclude. However, hazardous materials or banned materials may
be deposited upon the receipt of written permission of a responsible official or attendant of the agency and subject to any special instructions issued with
said permission. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991; amd. Ord. 1428, 11-27-2000)
4-5-14: BANNED SUBSTANCES:
No person shall deposit in a solid waste container or otherwise offer for City collection any banned substance. Banned substance shall be transported by
the owner, responsible person or his agent, to a place of safe deposit or disposal as prescribed by the City Manager or his authorized representative,
which place of deposit or disposal may in exceptional cases be a place other than an agency operated site or may be otherwise subjected to special
conditions or limitations. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-15: AGENCY DISPOSITION:
Pursuant to the terms of an agreement to be entered into between the City and the agency, the disposal sites now and hereafter operated by the agency
will be made available as public disposal sites for all solid wastes collected within the corporate limits of the City upon the conditions specified in the
agreement. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-16: DISPOSITION OF INERT MATERIALS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 246/687
The prohibitions contained in this chapter shall not apply to the placing of inert wastes, not potentially injurious to health or the public welfare, where
permission to place such materials has been obtained from the owner or responsible agent; nor to the filling in or grading of property with earth, mud,
ashes or similar materials; providing such actions are in compliance with all other applicable local and State laws. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-17: CONDITIONS SUBJECT TO ABATEMENT:
If any private disposal operation within the corporate limits of the City is found to be conducted in a way detrimental to the health and welfare of the public,
or contrary to provisions of this chapter, the City shall notify the owner of the land upon which such operation is being carried on and the operator thereof,
in writing, of the objectionable conditions and give them a reasonable time, not less than ten (10) days, to correct said condition. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990,
eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-18: FAILURE TO ABATE NUISANCE:
In the event of the failure of such owner or operator or both to correct such conditions within such time, the City Manager is authorized to seek abatement
of such conditions as a public nuisance and to abate such nuisance in such manner as any court of competent jurisdiction may direct. The same shall be
considered of benefit to the owner of the land and the cost of such corrective action shall be chargeable to the owner, and if not paid, shall constitute a lien
upon the premises and shall be assessed in the manner of a special assessment and collected in the same manner as general taxes as is provided by
law. (Ord. 940, 12-10-1990, eff. 1-1-1991)
4-5-19: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A. It is prohibited and will be deemed a violation hereof for any owner, lessee or occupant of any residential, commercial or institutional property in the City,
or any hauler providing service within the City, to put into or cause to be put into the solid waste collection system any yard waste or tree debris of any
size except as separated yard waste or tree debris of any size as provided herein or any banned substances. If any person violates any provisions of
this chapter, such person shall, upon conviction, be punished as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
B. In addition to the provisions set out in this chapter, the City may proceed in law or equity against any person for violation of any section or subsection of
this chapter. (Ord. 2289, 4-2-2018)
ARTICLE A. CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION ACTIVITIES
4-5A-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Article is to provide regulations pertaining to the disposal of construction or demolition material. (1985 Code §3-4.0201)
4-5A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall, after September 1, 1976, operate or permit the operation on his property of a disposal site in the City for the disposal of solid waste from
construction or demolition activities unless such person shall have first applied for and received a license to do so from the City. Such a license may be
issued by the City Council upon application by such person filed with the Building Inspector of the City; must be accompanied by a special use permit
issued by the City Board of Adjustment, and a State permit issued by the appropriate State agency to conduct a construction or demolition materials
disposal operation on the site in question; must demonstrate full present and contemplated compliance with the specific provisions of this Section and the
operational details and physical site proposals contained in plans accompanying the application, as well as the ability to do so; and shall be subject to
annual renewal by the City Council as hereinafter set forth. In reviewing the demolition landfill site application, the City Council must weigh the need for
such landfills to economically dispose of demolition and construction rubble against the inherent hazard, evaluated on the aforesaid information and
criteria and with professional advice as required. Such need must likewise be weighed against the potential for site pollution or danger to persons or
property who might predictably have direct or indirect contact with the site. To merit approval for licensing, such proposed operation must be demonstrated
by the application to be operationally feasible and to be substantially free of negative environmental effect as it is proposed to be operated upon the site
proposed. The application for a license to operate a disposal site for the disposal of solid waste from construction or demolition activities shall be
accompanied by the documentation described hereinafter. Plans for construction and demolition landfills shall be prepared under the direct supervision of
a registered engineer in conformity with chapter 114 of the Code of Iowa. Such requirement shall not preclude the inclusion in the application of reports of
geologists, architects, landscape architects, or such other disciplines as may be necessary or desirable to substantiate proposals contained in the
application. The plans shall show conformance to the following requirements. (1985 Code §3-4.0202)
4-5A-3: LOCATION OF SITE:
Sites for the disposal of demolition and construction materials shall be located in conformity with the following:
A. Flood Plain: The site shall be located outside of flood plain or riverfront land unless such requirement is waived by the appropriate State agency or
agencies.
B. Street or Highway: If the site is within one thousand feet (1,000') of a Federal or State highway or major City thoroughfare, the site must be satisfactorily
screened by natural objects, planting, fences or other.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 247/687
C. Water Supply: The site shall be at least one thousand feet (1,000') from any existing well that draws water for human or livestock consumption unless
hydrologic conditions are shown to be such that a greater or lesser distance is proper. (1985 Code §3-4.0203)
4-5A-4: ZONING AND LAND USE:
The application will be accompanied by a copy of the special use permit issued for such operation on the site by the City Board of Adjustment.
A. Present and Proposed Zoning: The plan submitted with the application shall be accompanied by a map showing all zoning within one thousand feet
(1,000') surrounding the site. The plan shall also indicate the land use proposed for the site after the filling is completed, although such indication shall
not be binding upon the City.
B. Comprehensive Plan Land Use: The plan submitted with the application shall indicate the land use shown for the site area in the future in the
comprehensive plan for the City. (1985 Code §3-4.0204)
4-5A-5: SITE PLAN:
The following particulars shall be included in maps of the site plan, as herein set forth, and shall accompany the application:
A. Scale: A map of the disposal site and immediate surroundings, on which a north arrow and scale of drawing are indicated. Generally, a scale of less
than one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') will not be approved.
B. Boundaries and Markers: The boundaries of the disposal site shall be shown thereon with sufficient data, including legal description, that a land
surveyor can easily locate the boundary. Natural and manmade monuments indicating the boundary shall be noted. Where the site is located in an
undeveloped area, four inch (4") boundary markers at least six feet (6') high and painted a bright color shall be used to identify the boundary so that
field inspection teams can easily identify the site.
C. Present Contour: Two foot (2') contours of the existing terrain shall be shown thereon.
D. Utilities: All existing utilities, including storm and sanitary sewers, which lead up to or cross the site shall be shown thereon.
E. Drainage: Existing and future drainage shall be shown thereon along with any proposed storm sewers.
F. Drill Holes: The location of the drill holes required by subsection 4-5A-8A shall be shown thereon.
G. Final Contours: Two foot (2') contours of the final proposed terrain shall be shown on a separate drawing. (1985 Code §3-4.0205)
4-5A-6: VICINITY MAP:
A map showing the area in the vicinity of the site, which shall be known as the vicinity map, shall be submitted, of a scale of one inch to six hundred feet
(1"= 600') or less; the area covered by the vicinity map shall be sufficient to contain the following:
A. Test Holes: Location of test holes for the monitoring of water quality and the findings from each.
B. Streets: Streets and street names, as well as all existing public right of way on and adjacent to the site.
C. Fire Hydrants: The nearest fire hydrants. Generally, if there is not a fire hydrant adjacent to the entrance drive and within three hundred feet (300') of the
active portion of the landfill site, a fire hydrant shall be so installed and connected with an appropriate extension of the water main. If covering and
compacting is performed daily, or if other equivalent means of providing fire protection are available, this requirement may be waived by the Council.
(See subsection 4-5A-9D.)
D. Haul Routes: The haul routes from the nearest City truck route.
E. Screening: Proposed screening of the site from highways, streets, parks, and residences and other amenities, as well as the schedule of installation of
such; such screening shall meet the requirements of the Zoning Ordinance and shall have been demonstrated to and approved by the Board of
Adjustment.
F. Private Wells: All private wells within one thousand feet (1,000') of the site shall be located and identified thereon.
G. Occupied Structures: All occupied homes and buildings on the site or within one thousand feet (1,000') of the boundaries thereof shall be shown, with
their addresses and uses indicated, by color coding or otherwise. (1985 Code §3-4.0206)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 248/687
4-5A-7: TRAFFIC:
The haul routes shown in the plan shall be reviewed by the Department of Public Works and City Engineer, or his representative, who shall make
recommendations thereon to the Council. Such haul routes shall be chosen to avoid undue hardships to residents living adjacent to them and to minimize
the likelihood of premature deterioration of City streets so chosen. (1985 Code §3-4.0207)
4-5A-8: SOILS AND GEOLOGY:
Information as to soil and geological conditions shall be provided as follows:
A. Geological Cross-Section: The plans shall contain a description of the drill holes shown on the site plan, which shall be sufficient in number to prepare
geological cross sections of the site, to facilitate a determination of the acceptability of the site location.
B. Water Table and Bed Rock: The water table depth and bed rock depth shall be indicated. If bed rock is excessively deep, it may be estimated.
C. Soil Report: A soil report shall be provided which indicates the acceptability of the soil on the site for cover material and the stability of the slopes after
the fill is complete. The vulnerability of the soil classification to erosion shall also be indicated. (1985 Code §3-4.0208)
4-5A-9: OPERATING SITE:
Plans for site operation, including the following, shall be provided.
A. Estimated Active Life and Volume: The estimated active life of the site and the total cubic dimensions of the area to be filled shall be indicated.
B. Annual and Peak Volume: The volume of construction and demolition material expected annually and on the peak days shall be indicated.
C. Cells: The number, size and shape of cells of demolition material shall be indicated.
D. Cover: The approximate depth and type of cover material shall be indicated. The volume of cover material needed for the entire site shall be indicated
as well as the source and soil classification of the cover material and frequency of covering. Once a week compacting of demolition material and
covering with dirt will be acceptable, provided a bulldozer with a blade, operator on call, and a stockpile of cover materials are available at all times on
the site in the event of fire. More frequent covering and compacting may be required by the city if it is deemed necessary to abate a nuisance and shall
be mandatory if the requirements of subsection 4-5A-6C, "Fire Hydrants", of this article are not met.
E. Gates And Fencing: The times at which the gates will be open as well as provisions for maintaining the fence at locations required herein shall be
indicated.
F. Vector Control: The intended continuing vector control, principally rat abatement and mosquito abatement, shall be indicated.
G. Personnel And Equipment: The personnel and equipment planned to operate the site, and the hours and days of the week when they will be on the
site, shall be indicated. (1985 Code §3-4.0209)
4-5A-10: SUMMARY OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS:
Expected environmental impact problems, with specific treatment or controls intended to eliminate or mitigate negative effects of each, shall be listed.
(1985 Code §3-4.0210)
4-5A-11: INSURANCE:
The applicant shall file a certificate of insurance evidencing the issuance to the applicant of liability insurance which shall protect the public and any and all
persons from injury which may be sustained by reason of the operation or condition of the landfill, and that the applicant carries insurance which meets the
requirements of the Iowa workmen's compensation law. Proof of such insurance shall show a minimum cancellation time of ten (10) days and shall
embody a requirement that the city shall have a right to such notice before such cancellation can become effective. The proof shall specify evidence of the
following forms of insurance protection.
A. Operation Liability: Liability insurance covering all operations performed by the licensed applicant and all persons in the licensed applicant's direct
employment.
B. Subcontractor: Public liability insurance covering all operations performed by any subcontractor or independent contractor to whom a portion of the
operations may have been assigned or which in the future may be assigned, or by any person or legal entity action for or on behalf of the licensed
applicant at or on the site.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 249/687
C. Vehicles: Motor vehicle bodily injury insurance and property damage liability insurance on motor vehicles employed on the site, whether or not owned
by the licensed applicant or by either the subcontractors or independent contractors under contract to the licensee, or by any other person or legal
entity acting for or on behalf of the licensed applicant at or on the site.
D. Amount: The main protection shall be insurance coverage with a minimum liability of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for the injury or death of any
one person and subject to the same limit per person, a minimum liability of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for the injury or death of any number of
persons in one accident, and a minimum liability of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for damage to property of others, but excluding property of the
insured. The insurance certificate shall provide that notice shall be given to the city clerk thirty (30) days prior to any cancellation or termination of
insurance. The cancellation or termination of the insurance shall automatically revoke the permit.
E. Additional Insured: The city shall be named as an additional insured under all liability policies without expense to it. (1985 Code §3-4.0211; amd. 1993
Code)
4-5A-12: LICENSE FEE:
An annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable to the finance director of the city shall accompany the initial application for license and
each application for renewal of the license. (1985 Code §3-4.0212; amd. 1993 Code; Ord. 1878, 8-23-2010, eff. 9-17-2010)
4-5A-13: RENEWAL REQUIREMENTS:
Applications for renewal need comply with the documentation requirements of sections 4-5A-2 through 4-5A-11 of this article only in the event there has
been a substantial change in the conditions or circumstances on or off the site which significantly affect the proposed operation or its effects during the
proposed renewal period, except that a showing must be made in such application that required insurance is in force and has continued in force during the
current license year. The application for such renewal must specifically negate or affirm the existence of any such circumstances or conditions and be
documented accordingly. The application for renewal must also be accompanied by a showing of a current permit, issued by the appropriate state agency,
for the operation of the construction or demolition materials landfill site. The building inspector, upon receipt of such application for renewal, shall process
the same as though it were an initial application for license, and shall report his findings and recommendations thereon, which shall be reviewed by the
council before issuance of the renewal. (1985 Code §3-4.0213)
4-5A-14: SITE ACCESSIBILITY:
The location of the fence and gates, which shall be provided to exclude people from the active fill site, shall be shown. They shall be located to prevent
illegal dumping, children from playing on the site, and debris from being blown off the site. The fence shall be at least six feet (6') high and composed of a
metal fabric and it shall comply with all street intersection setback requirements. The fence shall be constructed before landfill operations begin. For
purposes of this requirement, "active fill site" shall mean that portion of the land covered by the license which is in fact regularly receiving waste whether or
not at the instance of the applicant. The applicant shall maintain any unfenced area free of solid waste, and in the event of accumulation of waste upon or
abutting the site, the Building Inspector may require the applicant to install such further fencing as can assure that the then-active remainder of the site
shall remain free of unauthorized or improper accumulation of solid waste. (1985 Code §3-4.0214)
4-5A-15: SIGNING:
A prominent legible sign shall be provided at all site entrances indicating the name of the site owner and operator and emergency telephone numbers.
(1985 Code §3-4.0215)
4-5A-16: PUBLIC AGENCIES:
Neither the City or any other public agency shall be required to obtain the license required by this Article, but each such public body shall file with the
Council, before beginning operation and annually thereafter, evidence of substantial compliance with all provisions of this Article except the requirements
of Section 4-5A-4 of this Article. It is, however, specifically provided that such exemption from licensing shall not operate to exempt the City or other public
agencies from any other specific requirements of law relating to or regulating such operation to which such operation would otherwise be subject. (1985
Code §3-4.0216)
4-5A-17: PLAN CONTENT MANDATORY:
The operational details and physical site proposals contained in the plans filed with an application which has been approved by the City Council shall be
obligatory and binding upon the licensee, who shall conform to each such detail and proposal unless specifically relieved of such conformance by the
Council. (1985 Code §3-4.0217)
4-5A-18: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE RENEWAL:
In the event a licensee violates any section of this Article, as well as those made obligatory and binding upon the licensee by reason of their inclusion in
the application and approval by the Council, or other City ordinances, then the City Manager shall report the same to the Council, which shall set a public
hearing thereon and direct that the notice of the time, date and place of said public hearing and of the City Manager's report be given to the licensee. Such
hearing shall occur not less than ten (10) days after such notice has been mailed to the licensee at the address shown in the application or such other
address as has been provided by the licensee during the period of license. If, upon said hearing, the Council determines noncompliance by the licensee,
the Council may revoke or suspend the license or, if such determination be made while an application for renewal is pending, may deny renewal of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 250/687
license. Notice of such revocation or denial following such hearing may be either by formal notice to the licensee at the appropriate address or by so
advising representatives of the licensee personally present at such hearing, or by any other means reasonably calculated to apprise the licensee of such
revocation or such denial. No person or other legal entity whose license shall have been revoked, or the renewal thereof denied, pursuant to this Section,
and no successors or assigns or other legal entities in which such person or other legal entity shall have a substantial interest may obtain a license
pursuant to this Article within the City for a period of two (2) years from date of cessation of activities at such landfill site pursuant to such revocation or
denial. The operation of a disposal site without having a presently valid license to do so shall be and is hereby prohibited. (1985 Code §3-4.0218)
ARTICLE B. TRANSFER STATIONS
4-5B-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Article is to regulate the location and operation of solid waste transfer stations. (1985 Code §3-4.0301)
4-5B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or permit the operation on its property, of a transfer station in the City unless such person shall have first applied for and received
a license to do so from the City. A license to operate a transfer station shall be issued by the Council upon application filed with the Building Inspector of
the City and accompanied by a special use permit issued by the City Board of Adjustment, and a State permit issued by the appropriate State agency, to
conduct a transfer station operation on the site in question. The applicant must show proof that he can demonstrate full present and contemplated
compliance with the specific provisions of this Article and the operational details and physical site proposals contained in plans accompanying the
application, as well as the ability to do so; and shall be subject to annual renewal by the Council as hereinafter set forth. In reviewing such application, the
Council must weigh the need for the transfer station against the potential for site pollution, danger to persons or property likely to have direct or indirect
contact with the site, the feasibility of the operation, the likelihood of freedom from negative environmental effect of such operation, and such other factors
as shall reflect the public interest in balance against the interests of the applicant to operate such a facility on the site in question. (1985 Code §3-4.0302)
4-5B-3: APPLICATION:
The application for a license to operate a transfer station shall be accompanied by plans prepared under the direct supervision of a registered engineer in
conformity with chapter 114 of the Code of Iowa. The site as shown on the plans shall physically conform to the following requirements, and the application
shall contain either sufficient written information to show such conformity or it shall be shown by depiction of physical detail on the plan, as applicable.
(1985 Code §3-4.0303)
A. Site: The site shall be located outside flood plain or riverfront land unless such requirement is waived by the appropriate governmental agency or
agencies. The boundaries of the site shall be shown on the plan with sufficient data, including legal description, that a land surveyor can easily locate
the boundaries. Two foot (2') contours of the existing terrain shall likewise be shown on the plan. Proposed screening of the site from highways, streets,
parks, residences and other amenities, as well as the schedule of installation of such, shall be shown; such screening shall meet the requirements of
the zoning ordinance and shall have been demonstrated to and approved by the City Board of Adjustment. The site shall be enclosed with a chain link
fence not less than six feet (6') in height, which fence shall completely surround all portions of the site intended to be used in connection with the
operation of the transfer station. The location of such fence shall be shown on the plan.
B. Permits: The application will be accompanied by a copy of the special use permit issued for such operation by the City Board of Adjustment and by a
copy of the permit issued by the applicable State agency, each approving the operation of a transfer station on the site.
C. Vehicular Travel: The plan shall show the areas on the site over which haul vehicles and transfer equipment will travel. Such areas shall be
hardsurfaced, and the thickness and composition of such surfaces shall be shown on the plans. Barricades of a semi-permanent nature, affixed to the
ground, shall be placed to prevent vehicular travel on unsurfaced areas on the site; the location of such barricades shall be shown on the plan. The
haul road routes from the nearest City truck route shall be shown and identified on the plan. Such routes shall be reviewed by the Engineering
Department, who shall make recommendations thereon to the Council. Such haul roads shall be chosen to avoid undue hardship to residents living
adjacent to them and to minimize the likelihood of premature deterioration of City streets so chosen.
D. Unloading Area: All unloading, compacting and transfer activities shall be conducted within a fully enclosed structure or structures. Each such structure
shall be clearly depicted on the plan, with dimensions, in such fashion as to clearly show the type and location of equipment, the proposed routing of
unloading and transfer vehicles, all vehicle entrance and exit facilities to and from such structure or structures, and the waiting area for unloading
vehicles, which shall be sufficient to accommodate expected traffic. Such structures and waiting area shall be of sufficient size and appropriate design
as will assure that the volume of vehicles expected on site at any one time can be accommodated without spill-over on surrounding streets.
E. Drainage and Sewers: Floor surfaces in each unloading, compacting and transfer structure shall be so constructed that they can be cleaned by flushing,
and that they will permit the drainage of liquids without ponding; all such floor surfaces shall be equipped with floor drains or sump pump and with a
trap or other mechanical device which shall prevent the passage of solids, which system shall be connected to a sanitary sewer. A storm drainage
system for the site shall provide adequate storm drainage with minimum ponding and shall connect to a storm sewer. All interior drainage lines from the
unloading, compacting and transfer areas as well as other drainage lines within the site shall be adequate to handle the volumes of water and liquids
which may be expected. All drainage and sewerage systems, floor drains, floor surfaces construction and locations of connections to sewers shall be
clearly identified in the plan, showing dimensions and composition where appropriate.
F. Sanitation and Environmental Control: All solid waste shall be confined to unloading, compacting and transfer structures, and all solid waste remaining
at the transfer station at the end of each day shall be stored in leakproof, flyproof, and rodentproof containers. Vector control, principally rat abatement
and mosquito abatement, shall be the responsibility of the operator. The transfer station site shall be kept in a suitable clean and sanitary condition at
all times. The application shall list the provisions at the site and the schedule for cleaning vehicles, structures and grounds, as well as the intended
continuing vector control.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 251/687
G. Fire Prevention: Burning of solid waste, either open or controlled, is prohibited at the transfer station site. If a fire hydrant is not located adjacent to the
property and within three hundred feet (300') of the unloading, compacting and transfer structure or structures, then a fire hydrant shall be so installed
and connected to an appropriate extension of the water main. The location of the nearest fire hydrants to the transfer station shall be shown on the
plan, as shall such installations and extensions, where applicable.
H. Equipment: The transfer station shall be so designed and maintained that the operational failure of one component part will not result in a total
shutdown of the operation. An inventory of the equipment to be used in connection with the unloading, compacting and transfer operation shall be
contained in the application, as well as a list of backup equipment available or, failing direct availability, the sources from which such equipment shall
be obtained in the event of need.
I. Prohibited Materials: Sewage solids or liquids and hazardous wastes shall not be unloaded or accepted at the transfer station. Solid waste material of
such bulk as cannot be accommodated by direct transfer shall likewise be excluded from the transfer station.
J. Recycling: If the operation of the transfer station includes isolation, segregation and gathering of materials of a like or similar kind for salvage and
reutilization by recycling, the equipment, methods, and proposed operation in connection therewith shall be fully depicted and described in the
application. Solid waste which is received at the transfer station site and which is not thereat separated for recycling may only be disposed of by
hauling to a sanitary disposal project which has been approved by the appropriate governmental agency or agencies and is legally operating.
Scavenging at the transfer station site shall be prohibited, and all materials so separated and gathered for salvage and reutilization by recycling shall
be retained in suitable containers as heretofore described until removed by appropriate vehicles to off-site destinations,
K. Personnel and Hours: The personnel planned to operate the site, the times during which the gates will be open, and the hours and days of the week
during which the site will be open to receive solid waste shall be indicated in the application. Appropriate signs meeting the requirements of the Zoning
Ordinance for the district in which located shall be located at all entrance gates, shall be lighted if appropriate, shall identify such hours, shall list
prohibited materials, and shall contain such further information as will assure conformance of visitors to the site to the requirements of this Article. An
attendant shall be on duty at the site at all times when it is open for public use. (1985 Code §3-4.0303)
4-5B-4: INSURANCE:
The applicant shall file a certificate of insurance evidencing the issuance to the applicant of liability insurance which shall protect the public and any and all
persons from injury which may be sustained by reason of the operation or condition of the transfer station, and that the applicant carries insurance which
meets the requirements of the Iowa workmen's compensation law. Proof of such insurance shall show a minimum cancellation time of ten (10) days and
shall embody a requirement that the City shall have a right to such notice before such cancellation can become effective. The proof shall specify evidence
of the following forms of insurance protection:
A. Operations Liability: Liability insurance covering all operations performed by the licensed applicant and all persons in the licensed applicant's direct
employment.
B. Subcontractor Liability: Public liability insurance covering all operations performed by any subcontractor or independent contractor to whom a portion of
the operations may have been assigned or which in the future may be assigned, or by any person or legal entity acting for or on behalf of the licensed
applicant at or on the site.
C. Vehicle: Motor vehicle bodily injury insurance and property damage liability insurance on motor vehicles employed on the site, whether or not owned by
the licensed applicant or by either the subcontractors or independent contractors under contract to the licensee, or by any other person or legal entity
acting for or on behalf of the licensed applicant at or on the site.
D. Amounts: The main protection shall be insurance coverage with a minimum liability of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for the injury or death of any
one person and subject to the same limit per person, a minimum liability of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for the injury or death of any number of
persons in one accident, and a minimum liability of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for damage to property of others, but excluding property of the
insured. The insurance certificate shall provide that notice shall be given to the city clerk thirty (30) days prior to any cancellation or termination of
insurance. The cancellation or termination of the insurance shall automatically revoke the permit.
E. Additional Insured: The city shall be named as an additional insured under all liability policies without expense to it. (1985 Code §3-4.0304; amd. 1993
Code)
4-5B-5: LICENSING:
A. License Fee; Renewal: An annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable to the finance director shall accompany the initial application for
license and each application for renewal of the license. The provisions of article A of this chapter for renewal of license for construction or demolition
materials disposal sites shall likewise apply to the annual renewal of a transfer station license. (1985 Code §3-4.0305; amd. 1993 Code; Ord. 1878, 8-
23-2010, eff. 9-17-2010)
B. Public Agencies: Neither the city nor any other public agency shall be required to obtain the license required by this article, but each such public body
shall file with the council, before beginning operation and annually thereafter, evidence of substantial compliance with all provisions of this article
except the requirements of sections 4-5B-2 and 4-5B-4 of this article and subsections A and C of this section. It is, however, specifically provided that
such exemption from licensing shall not operate to exempt the city or other public agencies from any other specific requirements of law relating to or
regulating such operation to which such operation would be otherwise subject. (1985 Code §3-4.0307)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 252/687
C. Revocation Or Denial: The provisions of article A of this chapter for revocation or denial of renewal of a license for construction or demolition materials
disposal sites shall apply to the license of a transfer station. (1985 Code §3-4.0307)
4-5B-6: DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE:
All persons operating a transfer station licensed under the provisions of this article shall deliver or cause to be delivered all solid waste coming within its
control to the Des Moines metropolitan area solid waste agency disposal site or sites. (1985 Code §3-4.0308)
ARTICLE C. FEES AND CHARGES
4-5C-1: FEES ESTABLISHED:
The member municipality will fix, establish and maintain and revise the same from time to time whenever necessary such rates, fees, rentals or other
