Council. The subject matter of an appeal may be the issuance of permits under this chapter, the concurrence of the City Forester in permits required
under other ordinances or policies, violation notices issued by the Code Enforcement Officer or City Forester, or other relevant matters involving the
interpretation and enforcement of this chapter.
B. The appeal shall be considered by the City Manager or designee within thirty (30) calendar days of receiving the appeal. Action by the Code
Enforcement Officer or City Forester shall be stayed until the decision of the City Manager or designee is rendered, unless the Code Enforcement
Officer or City Forester certifies to the City Manager or designee, after notice of appeal shall have been filed with him or her, that by reason of the facts
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 408/687
stated in the petition, a stay would, in his or her opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such a case, proceedings shall not be stayed unless
an injunction has been obtained from a court of record.
C. The City Manager or designee may reverse, affirm, modify, or waive, wholly or partially, any decision of the Code Enforcement Officer or City Forester,
or the City Manager or designee may grant, deny, or revoke any permit or license. The decision of the City Manager or designee shall be final. (Ord.
2083, 2-23-2015)
7-10-12: PROTECTION OF TREES:
All public trees and shrubs deemed to be saved during construction or reconstruction activities shall be protected by the developer or property owner from
damages or disturbances, including their root systems. Protective fences shall be placed and maintained at or beyond the drip line of public trees and
shrubs that are unaffected by approved excavation or construction activities, but are subject to damage during said activities. Any disturbance of any kind
within the fenced area shall be prohibited. Cutting, boring, and filling soil within the drip line of a public tree or shrub to be preserved shall be prohibited
unless otherwise approved by the City Forester. Soil compaction caused by any type of equipment shall not be allowed to occur over the protected area of
the root zone of any public tree or shrub unless approved by the City Forester. (Ord. 2083, 2-23-2015)
7-10-13: INTERFERENCE WITH THE CITY FORESTER, CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER, OR CITY EMPLOYEES ENFORCING
THIS CHAPTER:
It is unlawful for any person or property owner to hinder, obstruct, or otherwise interfere with the City Forester, Code Enforcement Officer, or employees of
the City while engaged in carrying out the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2083, 2-23-2015)
7-10-14: PENALTIES:
The following penalties shall be imposed upon any person or property owner who violates any provision of this chapter:
A. Any person or property owner who violates the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be punished as set forth in title 1, chapter 4 of this
Code.
B. In addition to the penalties provided above, any person or property owner found guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter may be required to pay
the cost of repair or replacement of such public tree or shrub. The replacement costs shall be determined in accordance with the latest version of "A
Guide for Plant Appraisal" as published by the International Society of Arboriculture and authored by the Council of Tree and Landscape Appraisers.
C. The City reserves the right to collect costs in addition to penalties. The imposition of any penalty of a violation of this chapter shall not be construed as a
waiver of the right of the City to collect the costs of removal or treatment of any tree or shrub in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
D. Public utilities may be held responsible for the replacement of any public tree or shrub which has been severely damaged or died in the opinion of the
City Forester as a result of the maintenance or new installation of utilities. The City Forester shall coordinate with the public utility appropriate and
reasonable replacement of said severely damaged or dead public tree or shrub in accordance with the "City Forestry Standards of Practice and
Specifications".
E. Property owners abutting the area on which the public tree or shrub is located shall be notified by the utility company forty eight (48) hours prior to the
commencement of any utility repair, maintenance, or replacement activities which will affect or harm the public tree or shrub. In cases of emergency
repair, the City Forester shall have the option to waive said notification. (Ord. 2083, 2-23-2015)
Chapter 11
PARK REGULATIONS
7-11-1: PURPOSE:
The city council has adopted certain park rules governing the use of and conduct in city parks. The term "city park(s)" as used herein refers to the city
parks, park facilities, and trails within city parks located within or without the corporation limits of the city. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
7-11-2: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations are established concerning the conduct and use of city parks, also regulating traffic and parking automobiles and
vehicles. Persons and vehicles authorized for activities related to public safety or maintenance are exempt from the regulations:
A. Use Of Roadways: No person shall ride or drive any automobile, motorcycle, moped, snowmobile or any other motorized vehicle in any public park
except on the established roads or designated areas.
B. Speed: No person shall ride or drive any automobile or other vehicle in a public park at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour1. (Ord. 1355, 3-
22-1999)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 409/687
C. Parking: Vehicles shall be parked in designated parking lots and marked stalls only, unless the parks and recreation director or designee has
specifically authorized parking on the grass or outside designated parking lots. No vehicle shall be parked or allowed to remain within or upon any park
area or facility for a period in excess of twenty four (24) hours. No person(s) shall obstruct or impede the normal flow of traffic within a park. (Ord. 2104,
7-13-2015)
D. Hitching Animals: No person shall ride a horse or other animal or operate any type of horse or animal drawn conveyance in a public park except by
permission of the director of parks and recreation.
E. Destruction Of Natural Environment: No person shall in any manner deface, injure or remove any tree, shrub, or plant standing or growing in a public
park or pick or destroy flowers or seeds growing therein, or remove nests or wildlife/wildfowl.
F. Fires: No fires shall be lighted or made in any public park except with the permission of the director of parks and recreation, provided that this
subsection does not apply to fires in stoves, ovens, grills, fire rings or fireplaces provided in any facility in the city parks for use in picnic cooking. Fires
may be prohibited entirely during posted periods.
G. Firearms, Weapons, Or Explosives: No person shall use firearms, explosives, weapons, firecrackers or fireworks in any public park except as otherwise
provided by any other section of this code. Fireworks displays may be allowed by permission of the director of parks and recreation and the fire chief.
H. Litter: No person shall deposit upon or litter the ground with any form of waste material. All waste shall be deposited in receptacles provided for such
purposes. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
I. Use Of Tobacco: No person, at any time, shall use tobacco of any kind while present on any city park property. Tobacco includes any product made or
derived from tobacco that is intended for human use, including any component, part, or accessory of a tobacco product. This includes, but is not limited
to, cigarettes, electronic smoking devices, cigarette tobacco, roll your own tobacco, smokeless tobacco, and dissolvable tobacco. "Electronic smoking
devices" means any device that can be used to deliver an aerosolized solution that may or may not contain nicotine to the person inhaling from the
device, including, but not limited to, an e-cigarette, e-cigar, e-pipe, vape pen, e-hookah, or other simulated smoking device. Nicotine products approved
by the United States food and drug administration for tobacco cessation shall be allowed within city parks. (Ord. 2140, 3-21-2016)
J. Defacing Of Public Property: No person shall write, mark or draw characters on or deface, injure or destroy any building, or part thereof, or
improvement, apparatus or fixture, wall or fence, drain or sewer located on or in any public park. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
K. Posted Notices: (Rep. by Ord. 1197, 9-9-1996)
L. Control Of Animals: All animals must be under the control of a person competent to restrain and control the animal, either by leash, cord, chain, or other
similar restraint not more than ten feet (10') in length, or properly restrained within a motor vehicle. The owner or person in charge of an animal shall
clean up and/or remove as soon as possible any excrement or droppings deposited by the animal on park property. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
The requirement of a restraint on an animal shall not apply to animals registered to use a designated off leash area of a park while in said off leashed
area and while abiding by all the rules and regulations of such designated off leash area. (Ord. 1566, 1-5-2004)
M. Hours: No person shall be in any public park between the hours of ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. or at any time duly posted
and designated by the director of parks and recreation. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
N. Safety: (Rep. by Ord. 1197, 9-9-1996)
O. Compliance With Rules: All persons shall abide by rules established by city ordinance or by the parks and recreation department and posted in park
areas and facilities.
P. Posting: No person shall post, fasten, paint or affix any placard, bill, notice or sign upon any structure, tree, stone, directional sign, fence or enclosure
along or within any park except by permission of the director of parks and recreation. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
Q. Moving Fixtures: (Rep. by Ord. 1197, 9-9-1996)
R. Grounds Alteration: No person shall cut or remove any wood, turf, grass, soil, rock, sand or gravel from any public park without written permission from
the director of parks and recreation. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
S. Consumption In Public Parks: The department of parks and recreation may establish facility use policies regarding alcoholic beverage possession,
consumption, and sales within park facilities. No person shall consume alcoholic liquor, beer, or wine while present upon Holiday Aquatic Center
premises, Valley View Aquatic Center premises, the designated beach and swimming area at Raccoon River Park, Crossroads Park, Western Hills
Park, Brookview Park, Woodland Hills Park, Maple Grove Park, or in any parking lot, driveway, or road within a city park. However, beer may be
possessed and consumed in any other public park owned or leased by the city, provided it is within individual cans not exceeding sixteen (16) ounces
in size. Dispensing from kegs shall be permitted only with written permission of the director under the rules adopted by the department for the Raccoon
River Park Nature Lodge, the Raccoon River Park Softball Complex, and during activities held pursuant to a city special event permit. Consumption of
wine shall be permitted in the nature lodge in accordance with department established facility use policies. Signs prohibiting the consumption or
possession of alcoholic liquors, wine, or beer shall be posted where appropriate. (Ord. 2022, 2-24-2014)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 410/687
T. Responsibility Of Adults: (Rep. by Ord. 1197, 9-9-1996)
U. Park Roads: No park road shall be used as a through street by any vehicle where posted.
V. Golfing: No person shall play or practice golf in any city park, except during supervised activities approved by the director of parks and recreation.
W. Prohibited Activities: The following activities are specifically prohibited in any public park or greenbelt:
1. Disposing Of Material: No person shall place, store or dump any organic or inorganic materials including raked leaves, grass clippings, compost,
construction material, firewood, paint, trash, debris, junk or any similar materials in park dumpsters or on park property.
2. Private Improvements: No person shall garden, mow or plant trees without written permission from the department of parks and recreation. No
person shall install other private improvements such as fences, play equipment, irrigation systems, or similar encroachments on park land.
3. Miscellaneous: No person shall remove or deposit snow on park land. No person shall bury animals on park land.
The parks and recreation department is authorized to monitor and enforce such rules and regulations. Enforcement procedures shall follow city code
procedures for either administrative abatement or municipal infraction as determined in the best interest of the city.
X. Swimming/Beach Use: Swimming shall be allowed in posted areas only, except for organized activities approved by the director of parks and recreation.
No swimming shall be allowed from boats. Inner tubes, air mattresses, or other beach toy type items shall be allowed in posted areas only.
Y. Ice Skating: Ice skating shall be allowed in posted areas only. Ice skating shall only be allowed when posted as safe. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
Z. Boating: A boat equipped with any size motor may be operated at a no wake speed on Raccoon River Park Lake, except for in areas designated as
"Non-Motorized And Electric Motors Only" zones. All other regulations under the code of Iowa, chapter 462A, shall apply. All sailboats with a mast
height measuring thirty six feet (36') or greater above from the water surface are prohibited on the Raccoon River Park Lake. Additionally, all sailboats
are prohibited on Raccoon River Park Lake when the lake water level reaches an elevation of one foot (1') above the concrete dock at the boat ramp.
(Ord. 1360, 5-3-1999)
AA. Fishing: Fishing activities in parks shall comply with the code of Iowa, chapter 481A.
BB. Sales In Parks: No sales activities or admissions shall be allowed in any park except with approval of the director of parks and recreation.
CC. Hunting: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any hunting activity on park property using a rifle, shotgun, bow and arrow or any other
means on land or in the water unless approved by official action of the park and recreation advisory board and the city council.
DD. Trapping; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person to place, locate, set, use or attempt to use on park property, any type of claw, spring or metal
trap of any nature on land or in the water, or to set, use or maintain any snare, pitfall, deadfall, spring gun, set gun or device of similar character or
purpose.
Exceptions: The city or its authorized agents are exempt from the above and may control or manage animals, birds, or insects pursuant to established
policies that have been approved by the city council.
EE. Camping: All overnight camping is prohibited unless written authorization is received from the director of parks and recreation. (Ord. 1355, 3-22-1999)
7-11-3: PENALTY:
Violations of this chapter are declared to be municipal infractions and may be punished as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. For violations of
subsections 7-11-2I, "Use Of Tobacco", 7-11-2S, "Consumption In Public Parks", and 7-11-2X, "Swimming/Beach Use", of this chapter, police officers or
designees shall enforce and be authorized to issue citation-complaints. Before issuing a citation-complaint, the police officer or designee shall verify that
the offender has previously received a warning against engaging in such conduct, or the offender has refused to discontinue engaging in such conduct
after the police officer or designee has advised the offender that such conduct must cease. A one hundred dollar ($100.00) civil penalty shall be imposed
for each violation where a citation-complaint has been issued. For violations of subsection 7-11-2C, "Parking", of this chapter, police officers or designees
shall be authorized to issue parking tickets as specified in title 6, "Motor Vehicles And Traffic", of this code. (Ord. 2140, 3-21-2016)
Chapter 12
LIBRARY REGULATIONS
7-12-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to adopt certain library rules governing the conduct of patrons of the library of the City. The term "library" as used herein
refers to the City Library Building located at 4000 Mills Civic Parkway, West Des Moines, Iowa. (Ord. 1363, 5-17-1999)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 411/687
7-12-2: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations are established concerning the conduct of patrons and use of library facilities, as follows:
A. Library patrons are expected to be engaged in the productive use of the library's resources. This includes reading, studying, researching, attending
programs and utilizing library material. Patrons have the right to use the library undisturbed and library employees have the right to work without undue
interference.
B. The library will not tolerate bullying in any library space, gathering, or program and staff will do all they reasonably can to create a safe space for all
library users, regardless of an individual's actual or perceived age, color, creed/denomination, national origin, race, religion, marital status, sex, sexual
orientation, gender identity, physical attributes/appearance, physical or mental ability or disability, ancestry, political party preference, political belief,
socioeconomic status, or familial status. Bullying is defined as the unwanted, aggressive use of physical, social, or mental/intellectual power to control,
harm, or humiliate another person in a repetitive or pervasive manner.
C. No person shall engage in any conduct which disturbs or interferes with the legitimate use of the library, as follows:
1. Refuse to follow reasonable directives or instructions from a library staff member.
2. Willfully annoy, bully, harass, or threaten another person.
3. Behave in a disorderly, loud, or boisterous manner, including loud conversations.
4. Interfere with another person's passage within the library or on library grounds.
5. Consume or possess alcoholic beverages unless the Library Board of Trustees has approved of an event or function at the library where alcoholic
beverages will be provided. The consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages shall be limited to that provided to those in attendance at the
approved library event or function, and shall be confined to a designated area within the library during the event or function.
6. Use or possess controlled substances on library grounds or be under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances in a manner that causes
public disturbance.
7. Possess any firearm, knife, or any device which could be used as a weapon or other weapon prohibited by City ordinance or State Statutes.
8. Deface or destroy library property.
9. Eat or drink in the library (unless eating or drinking is specifically allowed in an area or at a particular activity).
10. Use tobacco or smoke in the library, including the use of electronic cigarettes or vaping devices.
11. Sleep in the library, or exhibit the appearance of sleep.
12. Remain in the library after regular closing hours.
13. Solicit funds, "panhandle", or engage in commercial activity unless authorized by library administration.
14. Interfere with patrons' use of the library through poor bodily hygiene which is so offensive as to constitute a nuisance, or through excessive use of
perfume, cologne, or alcohol.
15. Bring animals into the library except as required by persons with disabilities.
16. Use sports equipment, skates, or a skateboard in the library.
17. Use any audio, personal communication, or computing device in a manner that is disturbing to other patrons. Cellphone ringers should be set to
silent or vibrate and device speakers muted or headphones used.
18. Campaign, leaflet, petition, interview, or survey patrons or staff in a manner that is disruptive to library activities.
19. Willfully expose patrons and staff to offensive images or language.
20. Engage in lengthy conversations (including conversations on cellphones) in areas intended for quiet study.
21. Interfere with the library's right to maintain a clean, pleasant, and safe facility.
22. Relocate or rearrange furniture beyond repositioning existing seating around tables.
23. Be in any state of inappropriate undress.
24. Engage in sexual activity of any kind, including inappropriate displays of romantic affection.
25. Bring luggage, bedrolls, or large bags into the library.
26. Leave packages, backpacks, or personal belongings unattended. Personal property must be within sight of the owner. The library assumes no
responsibility for belongings left unattended. Large or possibly valuable belongings left on the premises after closing will be forwarded to the Police
Department.
27. Use bathrooms for unreasonable or unintended purposes, such as bathing or laundering. (Ord. 2321, 7-23-2018)
7-12-3: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 412/687
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be punished not in excess of a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine or in excess
of thirty (30) days' imprisonment. (Ord. 1363, 5-17-1999)
Chapter 13
SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS FOR STREETS
7-13-1: PURPOSE:
A. The purpose of this Chapter is to provide general guidance to staff and notice to citizens concerning the processes utilized to establish special
assessments for street improvements which will be levied upon private property in West Des Moines. Whenever the word "assessment" or words
"special assessment" are used in this Chapter, the word or words refer only to special assessments for street improvement projects, including
construction, paving, reconstruction, resurfacing or repair measures.
B. It is realized that special situations will arise which cannot be anticipated in a general policy but which will need to be addressed in a reasonable manner
once they arise. While this Chapter cannot be literally applied to every such exceptional situation, it is nonetheless the directive of the City Council that
the concepts reflected in this Chapter be fairly and equitably applied in a reasonable fashion to all street assessments. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-2: SCOPE:
A. Policy: It is the policy of the City to eventually have all streets within the City paved or widened to the extent suitable to their intended or actual use. All
street improvement projects shall be assessed in accord with this Chapter (as limited by the purpose) to the extent such improvement benefits property
in a definable benefited property district or area.
B. Other Finance Mechanisms: The City Council recognizes that not all streets are improved through use of a special assessment and that developers and
others may finance the improvement of streets through the use of other mechanisms. Where such alternative mechanisms have effectively shifted
costs to benefited property owners, even when not formally assessed, such property owners shall be treated as if their property had been previously
assessed. The City will not ordinarily place the same tract of land in more than one benefited property district for assessment purposes.
C. Street Width; Special Benefit: The amount assessed for any street improvement project shall normally be equivalent to constructing, paving, repairing,
or widening a local street in accordance with the current Urban Design Policy Standards Manual and the Urban Specifications for Construction of
Public Improvements (the "design standards") as adopted or amended by the City. In so limiting the amount of assessment, it is the intent of the
Council to assess only for the special benefit derived from a street improvement project; provided, however, that the City Council may in its discretion
assess up to the width of the classification of the street being improved, as provided in the design standards.
D. General Benefits: All general benefits from a street improvement project in excess of the above standard shall be paid from other City funds and shall
not be assessed. Subject to final determination by the Council, the percentage of general benefit to the City shall be determined in accordance with the
schedule set forth in subsection 7-13-3F of this Chapter.
E. Assessable Items: Assessable items, to the extent special benefits are conferred, shall include:
1. All related storm sewer for the project (but not all storm sewer costs and oversizing of drains necessitated by anticipated future expansion shall be
assessed).
2. All required grading for the project.
3. All utility relocations required due to the project.
4. All driveways, sidewalks, and trails required due to the project.
5. All surface restoration required by the project.
6. All right of way required due to the project up to sixty feet (60').
7. All the engineering fees associated with the design and construction of the project.
8. All legal fees associated with the project.
9. All appraisal fees associated with the project.
10. Pro rata share of administrative costs.
11. Paving costs.
12. Traffic signals where a special local benefit is conferred.
13. All other miscellaneous costs and contingency costs directly related to the project.
F. Design Standards: All standards and details of design for proposed assessment projects shall be in accordance with the design standards as amended
and the Comprehensive Plan as amended.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 413/687
G. Street Improvements: In addition to constructing new streets, the City may assess for street widening, reconstruction, repair or resurfacing when such
improvement is found to confer special benefits. Such assessment will ordinarily occur only in a manner consistent with this general statement, and
only to the extent that the property has not been assessed or owners have not otherwise previously participated directly in the cost of such
construction. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-3: PROCEDURE:
A. Procedural Steps: The City will generally endeavor to follow the procedural steps set out in this Section.
B. Identification Of Streets: City staff shall, during the budget process or as part of the citizens Capital Improvement Program, and at other times as
directed by the City Council, identify streets which in the opinion of staff should be considered for improvement. The City Manager shall review such
recommendations and report to the Mayor and City Council his or her findings as to the need for improvement. The City Council shall act upon such
recommendations as part of its annual budgetary process, either through consideration of capital improvement projects or at such times as may seem
proper in the circumstances.
C. Petition By Property Owners: As an alternative, assessments for street improvement projects may be initiated by petition of all property owners to be
assessed for the cost subject to Council approval. Such projects, however, shall normally be considered in light of the regular budgetary process.
D. Project Determination: After the initial considerations and discussions set forth above, the City Council shall decide whether it wishes to consider a
street improvement project and whether that project should be specially assessed. As part of such decision, the City Council shall direct the appropriate
eminent domain notice be issued, and may employ consulting engineers, bond counsel and such other consultants as may be necessary.
E. Preliminary Plat And Schedule Of Assessments: As part of the consideration of whether to levy special assessment for a project, the City Council shall
direct the engineer to prepare a preliminary plat and schedule of assessments, estimate the costs, and preliminary plans and specifications, and to
furnish necessary data to bond counsel needed to prepare legal proceedings. The engineer shall present a preliminary draft of the plat and schedule to
the City staff which shall review the documents and make recommendations to the City Council.
F. Arterial Or Collector Streets: All streets classified in the then current Comprehensive Plan as arterial or collector shall be considered to generally benefit
the community as well as specially benefited properties in the benefited property district. Therefore, any reduction in the special assessment shall
generally be applied to the specially affected parcel within one hundred fifty feet (150') of the street improvement project in accordance with the
following schedule:
Street
Classification
Amount
Of Reduction
Major arterial 40 percent
Minor arterial 20 percent
Major collector 10 percent
Minor collector 5 percent
The distance of one hundred fifty feet (150') on each side of the street shall generally be applied to create an area similar to the area established by
application of the Flint Formula, as further set forth in Section 7-13-9 of this Chapter. The final determination of any reduction, however, shall be
established by the City Council.
G. Property Valuation: The City Council shall determine the valuation of the property to be specially assessed. The valuations for property within the
proposed assessment district shall not exceed the fair market value of the property with the proposed public improvement in place. The City Council
shall retain the services of an MAI appraiser to advise the City Council as to its findings regarding the valuation of each lot and parcel within the
benefited property district with the street improvement in place.
H. Project Information Meeting: As part of the consideration of whether to levy a special assessment for a street improvement project, the City Council
shall either conduct a project information meeting or direct staff to conduct a project information meeting. Benefited property owners shall be notified by
letter with details concerning the proposed project and the time, location and place of the meeting. Staff shall arrange for the delivery of the notification
at least ten (10) days prior to the meeting.
I. Informational Pamphlet: Staff shall provide an informational pamphlet describing the project, assessment procedure, and pertinent deadlines along with
a copy of this Chapter to those attending the project information meeting and to others upon request. No official action shall be taken by the City
Council on the assessment proceeding within a thirty (30) day period following the project information meeting to permit affected property owners to
petition for or against the project.
J. Preliminary Plans And Specifications: At the completion of the above process, the preliminary plans and specifications, preliminary plat, schedule of
assessments, and estimate of costs shall be officially filed in the office of the City Clerk.
K. Council Resolutions: After the filing of the preliminary plans and specifications, preliminary plat, schedule of assessments, and estimate of costs, the
City Council shall meet to consider the preliminary resolution for the street improvement project, resolution fixing value of lots, resolution adopting
preliminary plat and schedule, estimate of costs, and preliminary plans and specifications. If the City Council adopts the foregoing, it shall then consider
a proposed resolution of necessity for the project and set a date and time for public hearing on the proposed resolution of necessity.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 414/687
L. Notice To Property Owners; Publication: Notice shall then be given to the affected property owners that the proposed resolution of necessity will be
considered by the City Council. The notice shall be published as required by law.
M. Resolution Of Necessity: The City Council shall hold a public hearing on the resolution of necessity. The City Council shall hear all objections and
endorsements and consider all filed and written objections. The City Council shall then officially continue or close the public hearing. After closing the
public hearing, the City Council may reject, adopt, or amend and adopt, the proposed resolution of necessity, or the City Council may defer action until
a subsequent meeting.
N. Required Vote: Passage of the resolution of necessity shall require the affirmative vote of three-quarters (3/4) of the City Council; provided, however, if
written remonstrances signed by the owners of seventy five percent (75%) of the amount of the proposed assessments on property subject to
assessment have been timely filed with the City Clerk, the resolution of necessity will require the unanimous affirmative vote of the City Council for
passage.
O. Plans And Specifications; Contract: If the resolution of necessity is adopted either as proposed or as amended, the City Council shall then adopt
resolutions directing the preparation of detailed plans and specifications, and the form of contract and notice to bidders.
P. Court Decree: Following the adoption of either the original or amended resolution of necessity when more than sixty percent (60%) of the amount of the
proposed assessments on property subject to assessment have petitioned against the project, the City Council may direct bond counsel or other legal
counsel to file in District Court a petition requesting the Court to review and confirm the proposed street improvement by decree. The City Council, at its
own discretion, retains the option of having other assessments for street projects confirmed by the same process.
Q. Detailed Plans And Specifications: Detailed plans and specifications and the form of contract and notice to bidders shall officially be placed on file in the
City Clerk's office.
R. Resolution Ordering Bids; Approving Plans: The City Council shall, either at the meeting at which the resolution of necessity is adopted, or thereafter,
adopt a resolution ordering bids, approving plans, specifications and form of contract, and notice to bidder; fixing amount of bid security; ordering City
Clerk to publish notice, fix a date for reviewing bids; and for a public hearing on plans, specifications, form of contract and estimate of costs. The notice
to bidder shall then be published as required by law.
S. Filing With County Treasurer: The resolution of necessity and preliminary plat and schedule of assessments shall be filed in the county treasurer's office
as required by State law. The City Clerk shall also execute a certificate with regard to the amount of agricultural deferment requests timely filed by
property owners pursuant to Section 7-13-5 of this Chapter.
T. Public Hearing; Resolution Awarding Contract: The City Council shall hold a public hearing on the plans, specifications, and form of contract as required
by the published notice. After the public hearing is complete, the Council may adopt the resolution adopting plans, specifications, form of contract, and
estimated cost. Bids which have been received for the street improvement project shall be evaluated by City staff and, where appropriate, consulting
engineers and legal counsel. If satisfactory bids have been received, the City Council may adopt a resolution awarding a contract, or the City Council
may defer action, or for proper reasons reject all bids.
U. Review Of Completed Work: After completion or substantial completion and in accordance with law, the engineer shall review the completed work and
file certificates of completion and final estimates of costs with the City Clerk. The total project cost and the total assessable cost of the project shall be
summarized by category with a full description of costs, including unit quantities, available to the public on request.
V. Resolution Accepting Work; Levy Of Final Assessments: The City Council shall then adopt a resolution accepting the work and ordering preparation of
the final plat and schedule of assessments. The final plat and schedule of assessment shall be filed by the engineer in the City Clerk's office. The
resolution adopting and levying the final assessments and providing for the payment thereof shall then be adopted by the City Council. In no case may
the final assessments be greater than the preliminary assessment. Notice of filing of the final plat and schedule shall be given as required by law.
W. Final Plat And Schedule Filed With County Treasurer; Notice To Property Owner: The City Clerk shall file a certificate of levy and copy of the final plat
and schedule in the office of the county treasurer and the Building Permit Official's office. Notice of such filing shall be published for two (2) consecutive
weeks with the first publication not more than fifteen (15) days from the date of filing the final plat and schedule with the county officials. On or before
the date of the second publication of notice, the Clerk shall send, by ordinary and certified mail, a copy of the notice to each property owner. (Ord.
1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-4: PAYMENT OF ASSESSMENTS:
A. Any assessment levied under this Chapter may be paid in full or in part without interest within thirty (30) days after the date of certification.
B. Except as to assessments of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), which must be paid in full before the next July 1, assessments may be paid, with
interest, in installments with real estate taxes over a period of ten (10) years. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-5: AGRICULTURAL DEFERMENT:
A. Persons having a tract of land, either alone or as an integral part of a larger tract, which is both used and assessed for agricultural purposes, and which
would otherwise be subject to assessment, may apply for an agricultural deferment as provided by State law.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 415/687
B. Any property owner who seeks deferment of an assessment shall file a written request for deferment with the City Clerk at the time of the hearing on the
resolution of necessity or within ten (10) days following the date of the closing of the public hearing. The request shall identify those lots subject to the
proposed assessment which the property owner claims are entitled to agricultural deferment.
C. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to make such additional annual filings as are required by law for the continuation of an agricultural
deferment. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-6: DEFICIENCY ASSESSMENTS:
A. If the proposed assessment is greater than twenty five percent (25%) of the value of any tract with the improvement in place, the Council shall provide
by resolution that the portion of the assessment which exceeds twenty five percent (25%) of the value of the tract with the improvement in place shall
be certified to the county treasurer as a deficiency.
B. The amount of the deficiency shall amortize over a period of ten (10) years and after ten (10) years no part of the deficiency may be assessed;
provided, however, that if a private improvement is constructed on a lot subject to deficiency during the period of amortization, the pro-rata deficiency
on the lot which has not been amortized shall be assessed to the extent that it is assessable. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-7: ASSESSMENT METHODS:
A. The City Council has elected to use formulas as a guide to the exercise of its legislative power to determine the proper amount to be assessed against
property which receives a special benefit from a street improvement project. Depending upon the character of the street to be improved, the City will
utilize a method of assessment which assures that the assessable costs of a street improvement project are fairly spread among benefited properties
and that no property is assessed an amount greater than the special benefit received.
B. In its sole legislative discretion, the City Council shall determine whether the application and use of a formula to guide it in establishing the amount of
individual assessments meet the criteria established by this Chapter and the law. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-8: BENEFITS:
A. Benefit Conferred: It is the policy of the City not to assess any amount for street improvements in excess of the benefit conferred on a lot or parcel.
Benefits resulting from street improvements which inure to property owners within the assessment area will depend upon the circumstances of each
project.
B. Nature And Extent Of Benefits: As a result of street improvement projects, property owners often benefit from enhanced access, an improved
environment because of dust and drainage control, enhancement of aesthetic qualities in the area, a decrease in the cost of automobile and other
vehicle maintenance, an improvement in the ability of police, fire, ambulance and other public safety organizations to respond, an increase in the value
of property, and an improvement in the ability of property owners to market their property either for present uses or possibly new uses. Moreover, the
nature and extent of benefits may vary depending upon conditions in the area of the improvement including such factors as topography, the level of
economic activity, and the level or nature of economic development.
C. Not Exhaustive Discussion: Any discussion in this Chapter of specific special benefits is not to be construed as exhaustive or illustrative of all benefits
which may in any particular project inure to the benefit of property owners; and this Chapter is neither intended to be, nor to be construed as a
complete or definitive discussion of the special benefits to be derived from street improvement projects. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-9: MODIFIED FLINT FORMULA:
A. In areas of the City laid out in a traditional grid or similar pattern, a modified Flint Formula shall be used to determine assessments. Streets to be
assessed by this method shall be largely those commonly known as infill streets. All property within three hundred feet (300') of the right of way or onehalf
(1/2) the distance to the next parallel street (whichever distance is less) shall be assessed benefit calculated upon a curve which applies
incrementally less benefit to parcels of property located a greater distance from the proposed improvements.
B. A depth factor chart and proximity curve, as adopted by the City Council and on file with the City Clerk's office, shall be used in calculating assessments
levied under this method. The curve may, however, be modified by the City Council for any street improvement project where reason or circumstances
require such modification. Moreover, the Council may modify any proposed assessment which results from the application of the curve where reason or
circumstances make such modification reasonable or just. All modifications, however, shall be limited to the extent necessary to reflect actual special
benefit conferred on the lot or parcel. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-10: AREA (DISTRICT) ASSESSMENT METHOD:
A. The area (district) assessment method shall be used for the assessment of all streets which confer local benefit outside the traditional grid pattern as
set forth in Section 7-13-9 of this Chapter. It is the intent of the Council that all property served outside the traditional grid pattern be assessed for the
street improvement which provides access and other special benefits in accord with City street and development plans, but that no parcel shall
generally be assessed more than once for such improved street.
B. The area (district) assessment method may be combined with any other method of assessment if the Council finds such combination is necessary in
order to properly determine special benefits in an area. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 416/687
7-13-11: BOUNDARIES OF ASSESSMENT DISTRICTS FOR AREA (DISTRICT) ASSESSMENT:
A. The boundaries of an area to be assessed in an area (district) assessment shall be established in accord with this Section and shall include the
benefited land on both sides of the street to be improved. The line demarcating the boundaries shall commence at the intersecting streets at the
terminus of the street improvements and bisect the land area to be served by the public improvement and the intersecting streets so as to divide the
service area of the streets. Where actual bisection is inappropriate because of street patterns, land divisions, natural or other barriers, adjustments will
be made to accommodate such patterns, barriers or divisions. The assessment district shall be established based upon the area served or otherwise
benefited by the street improvement.
B. In determining actual boundaries, all property which reasonably receives a special benefit shall be included in the district. To establish district
boundaries, consideration shall be given to topography, land division lines, planning and development criteria regarding land use in the district, actual
and present land use, the need to plan for and provide access to adjacent areas, the need to coordinate access to adjacent areas, plans for the use
and the actual use of adjacent areas, actual and projected street and transportation patterns, and the relationship of the street improvement project to
other planned, projected, or existing public improvements. Where possible all land within one subdivision should be included within a single area
assessment district. In establishing boundaries, all lots on a street which provide access to the street being improved should be included in the same
district.
C. The City Council shall make the final determination of the boundaries of the district after holding a public hearing pursuant to subsection 7-13-3M of this
Chapter, giving consideration to the provisions of this Chapter, the advice and judgment of engineers and other consultants, and such other
considerations as it deems appropriate to its determination. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
7-13-12: METHODOLOGY:
A. Special Benefit Conferred: In the application of the area assessment method, the City shall generally follow the method set out below, reserving,
however, to the City Council the right to vary, amend, or otherwise change the formula or method or the application of either, where such modification is
necessary in order to properly reflect in the assessment the special benefit conferred by a street improvement project.
B. Area Distribution: After the benefited area has been preliminarily determined, the assessment shall be distributed over the entire area based upon the
area of each lot included in the district. The resulting calculation shall constitute the base assessment rate for the public improvement project. For
purposes of assessment, a lot shall be defined consistent with the definition in Iowa Code section 384.37.10 (1999) as an actual platted lot or any other
tract of land under common ownership.
C. Direct Access Lots: Lots within an area of depth up to one hundred fifty feet (150') which have, or could reasonably have, direct vehicular access by
driveway, or otherwise, onto the public improvement shall be assessed at a rate of two (2) times the base assessment rate in the area. Any portion of a
lot with direct access within an area of depth greater than one hundred fifty feet (150') shall be assessed at the base assessment rate.
D. Abutting Lots: Abutting lots shall be defined consistent with the definition in Iowa Code section 384.37.1 (1999) as lots which abut or join the street in
which the public improvement is located or which abut the right of way of the public improvement. Lots within an area of depth up to one hundred fifty
feet (150') which abut the public improvement, but which lack direct access by driveway or otherwise, shall be assessed at a rate of one and one-half
(11/2) times the base assessment to reflect the special benefit of proximity to the street improvement project. Any portion of abutting lots within an area
of depth greater than one hundred fifty feet (150') shall be assessed at the base assessment rate.
E. Adjacent Lots: Adjacent lots shall be defined consistent with the definition of Iowa Code section 384.37.2 (1999) as lots within the district which do not
abut upon the street or right of way of the public improvement. Adjacent lots within an area of depth up to one hundred fifty feet (150') shall be
assessed at a rate of one and one-half (11/2) times the base assessment rate to reflect the special benefit of proximity to the street improvement
project. Any portion of adjacent lots within an area of depth greater than one hundred fifty feet (150') shall be assessed at the base assessment rate in
the area.
F. Subdivided Lots; Preliminary Plat; Development Agreement: Parcels which abut the street improvement, but have not been subdivided into residential
lots at the time of the preliminary schedule of assessments, even though such lots could be divided into residential lots, shall be considered to have
direct access to the public improvement and shall be assessed to a depth of one hundred fifty feet (150') at a rate of two (2) times the base rate of
assessment in the area; provided, however, that if a preliminary plat is filed and approved, or a development agreement is executed with the City, prior
to the passage of the resolution of necessity, the lots shown by such plat or agreement shall be used to determine the rate of assessment. Any
development agreement executed pursuant to this subsection shall be recorded.
G. City Council Final Determination: The City Council shall make the final determination by reviewing the formula results, and may adjust the formula, or
the results as to the entire area, individual lots or both, in order to achieve a fair and just distribution of any assessment in accord with the special
benefit conferred by the improvement project to lots in the assessment district. (Ord. 1389, 10-4-1999)
Chapter 14
UTILITY SYSTEMS
7-14-1: SUBJECT TO CITY APPROVAL:
A. All installation, replacement or upgrade of cables, wires and conduits in connection with any utility system shall require submission of detailed plans to
the city, of detailed plans clearly indicating proposed work and all applicable city permits shall be approved by the city before proposed utility work
commences.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 417/687
B. All utility work shall comply with the city's current design standards and standard construction specifications. (Ord. 1432, 1-8-2001, eff. 1-8-2001)
7-14-2: PLACEMENT UNDERGROUND:
A. Underground: All cables, wires and conduits in connection with any utility system shall be placed underground, except as provided in subsection B of
this section.
B. Exceptions: Underground installation shall not be required in the following situations:
1. Electric lines of nominal voltage in excess of fifteen thousand (15,000) volts.
2. Where aboveground connection to building or other location is reasonably necessary, as determined by the public works director.
3. Where another section of this code specifically allows aboveground placement.
4. Replacement or upgrade of aboveground cables and wires where the length of replacement or upgrade does not exceed three hundred feet (300').
5. Electric transformers, telephone and cable TV pedestals, and any other appurtenances in connection with any utility system, as approved by the
public works director.
6. Replacement of support poles, for aboveground cables, when the segment of pole replacement does not exceed three hundred feet (300').
7. When the public works director deems an exception to be in the best interest of the city.
C. Upgrade And Replacement Of Existing Systems: The provisions of subsection A of this section shall apply to any system upgrade, including
replacement or relocation of existing utility cables, wires or conduits.
D. All Parts Of City: The application of this chapter shall apply to all areas of the city and shall not be limited to public ways, property, and easements.
(Ord. 1432, 1-8-2001, eff. 1-8-2001)
7-14-3: PLACEMENT ABOVEGROUND:
A. Structures within city street right of way:
1. Structures associated with any cables, wires or conduits in connection with any utility system shall not be placed within the street "clear zone", as
defined in the city's current design standards and standard construction specifications, except as directed by city council. Should, after city council
approval, said structures be placed within the street "clear zone", as defined herein, it will be the responsibility of the utility company to provide, at no
cost to the city, all barricades, safety measures, etc., as deemed necessary by the public works director, for any structure in connection with any
utility system that is placed within the said street "clear zone", defined herein.
2. All aboveground structures associated with any cables, wires or conduits in connection with any utility system shall be maintained by the respective
utility so as to be plumb, secured to prevent unauthorized entrance and finished, where appropriate, to be aesthetically attractive. (Ord. 1432, 1-8-
2001, eff. 1-8-2001)
7-14-4: VIOLATION:
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be subject to civil penalty of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each violation or, if the infraction is a repeat offense, a civil penalty not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each repeat offense. (Ord. 1432,
1-8-2001, eff. 1-8-2001)
Chapter 15
PUBLIC ARTS
7-15-1: PURPOSE; POLICY:
A. The purposes of this chapter are to promote the cultural heritage and artistic development of the city, to enhance the city's character and identity, to
contribute to economic development and tourism, to add warmth, dignity, beauty, and accessibility to public spaces and to expand the experience and
participation of citizens with visual arts, by directing the inclusion of public arts in appropriate city capital improvement program projects.
B. The city council recognizes the importance of the creation, support, and maintenance of public arts. The city council shall fund the public arts program
with a portion of hotel/motel funds as determined annually in the adoption of the final budget. The funds shall be used for artist design services and for
the selection, acquisition, display, and maintenance of artworks. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to this chapter and any policies, guidelines, and procedures that may be developed to implement the public arts
program plan:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 418/687
ARTIST: Any practitioner in the visual and design arts, generally recognized by critics and peers as a professional in the field as evidenced by his or her
education, experience, exhibition record, and artwork production.
ARTWORKS: Works in a variety of media produced by professional artists; works may be permanent, temporary, or functional, and may be stand alone or
integrated into the architecture or landscaping, if such are designed by an "artist" as defined herein, and should encompass the broadest range of
expression, media, and materials. The term "artworks", does not include ineligible expenditures as described in section 7-15-4 of this chapter.
"Artworks" include:
A. "Sculpture": Sculptures may be made of any material or combination of materials; they may be freestanding, wall supported, or suspended, kinetic,
electronic, or mechanical.
B. "Murals" Or "Paintings": Murals or paintings may be made of any materials or combination of materials with or without collage; they may be made by
traditional or nontraditional means.
C. "Other": Earthworks, neon, glass, organic materials (fiber, clay, wood, etc.), mosaics, photographs, prints, literary expression, calligraphy, any
combination of forms of media, including audio, video, film, CD-ROM, DVD, holographic, or computer generated technologies or new genres.
"Artworks" as defined herein may be permanent, fixed, temporary, or portable, they may be an integral part of a building, facility, or structure, and may be
integrated with the work of other design professionals.
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (CIP): The city's program for capital development.
COMMISSION: The city's public arts advisory commission that advises the city council on expenditures from the public arts fund.
ELIGIBLE CONSTRUCTION PROJECT: Any permanent public improvement project paid for wholly or in part by the city, for the construction or renovation
of any building, park, highway, road or street, streetscape or road beautification, bridge, transit or aviation facility, trail or bikeway, decorative or
commemorative structure, viaduct or pedestrian overpass/underpass, parking facility, abovegrade utility, or any portion thereof, to which the public has
access or which is visible from a public right of way.
ELIGIBLE PROJECT COSTS: The total project appropriation, less real property acquisition, demolition, environmental remediation, legal and accounting
fees, and interest charges. It shall also exclude funding from any outside source, if such funds are not permitted to be used for artworks.
PUBLIC ARTS COLLECTION: The artworks owned by the city, regardless of whether they were accumulated before or after the effective date of this
chapter.
PUBLIC ARTS FUND (FUND): A separate account into which all monies generated under this chapter or derived from gifts or donations for public arts
shall be deposited.
PUBLIC PLACE: An area on public or private property that is legally accessible and visible to the general public.
RENOVATION: Any major redesign of a facility or system or portion thereof which is included in eligible construction projects, including expanding or
upgrading the capacity of the facility or system, or enlarging the facility or creating a new use for the facility. It does not include repairs, maintenance, or
installation of replacement mechanical equipment or modifications required solely for the purposes of code compliance. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-3: FUNDING:
A. Each year, the city council shall budget discretionary funds from the hotel/motel fund to be appropriated and expended for acquisition or commissioning
of artworks in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Appropriations for purposes of acquiring artworks in order to carry out the provisions of
this chapter shall be made in accordance with law and the budgeting procedures of the city. Development and placement of artworks shall be approved
by the city council.
B. Appropriations and expenditures for artworks may include, but are not limited to, the costs and expenses incurred in the process of designing,
fabricating, installing, and maintaining artworks in public buildings or grounds.
C. Any monies collected or designated in accordance with this chapter shall be deposited into the public arts fund by the finance director. The finance
director shall establish accounting records sufficient to identify and control these funds. The account containing these funds shall earn interest and the
earned interest shall be deposited in the city's general fund according to the code of Iowa. The public arts fund shall be authorized to accept gifts,
grants, and donations made to the city for artworks. The public arts fund shall be self-perpetuating from year to year. Subfunds will be established as
the finance director deems necessary to maintain compliance with public and private requirements.
D. Funds authorized or appropriated pursuant to this chapter may be expended for artworks in association with any current city projects or in existing
public facilities and spaces which are owned by the city, if legally permissible.
E. In the case of any eligible construction project which involves the use of grant funds, or the proceeds of any bonds issued, amounts for artworks shall
be used for projects and purposes consistent with state and federal laws, and the resolutions or policies approved by the voters or the city council, as
applicable.
F. Unless any monies collected for the public arts fund are designated for a specific purpose or project, the monies shall be pooled into this fund.
G. An amount equal to fifteen percent (15%) of the public arts allocation for each project shall be set aside in a separate account to be used for the public
arts program administration and community participation activities, including artist selection, design/proposal/maquette costs, consultant fees, project
documentation, publicity, community education activities, interpretive plaques, and other purposes as may be deemed appropriate by the commission
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 419/687
for the administration of the program. Funds in the program administration account not expended at the close of any fiscal year shall be carried forward
into the next fiscal year.
H. An amount equal to ten percent (10%) of the public arts allocation for each project shall be set aside in a separate account for curatorial services and
the preservation and maintenance of artworks in the public art collection. Funds in the maintenance and conservation account not expended at the
close of any fiscal year shall be carried forward into the next fiscal year.
I. The public arts fund shall be used to provide sites for artworks in public places, but shall not be used for the purchase of any easement. Public artworks
may be placed on public display, integral or attached to a public building or structure, detached within or outside a public building or structure, within or
as a part of the landscape of a public park, square, or other outdoor public site or lands, part of a portable exhibition or collection, part of a temporary
exhibition, or loaned or exhibited in other public facilities. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-4: INELIGIBLE EXPENDITURES:
Expenditures that would not be eligible include, but are not limited to:
A. Reproductions of original artworks by mechanical or other means; however, limited editions controlled by the artist, or original prints, cast sculpture,
photographs, etc., may be included;
B. Decorative, ornamental, or functional elements that are not designed by an artist selected through an approved selection process;
C. Those elements generally considered to be components of the landscape architectural design, vegetative materials, pool(s), paths, benches,
receptacles, fixtures, planters, etc., designed by the architect, landscape architect, or other design professional engaged by the primary designer;
D. Art objects which are mass produced or of a standard design, such as playground sculpture or fountains;
E. Directional or other functional elements, such as signage, color coding, maps, etc., not designed by an artist selected through the commission approved
process;
F. Purchase of existing artworks without the selection process as provided for in the adopted public arts program guidelines and principles;
G. Representations of historical figures or events, or historical plaques, not designed by an artist through the commission approved process;
H. Notwithstanding maintenance of the artworks, continuing operating expenses or maintenance of architectural elements on or in which the artworks are
placed, or sites where artworks are located; and
I. Notwithstanding architectural elements on or in which the artworks are placed or affixed or mechanical elements and utilities needed to activate the
artworks, which would be eligible expenditures, each installation will be reviewed individually to determine eligible expenditures. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-5: EXCLUSIONS; ADDITIONS:
A. Prior to submission of the city's proposed annual capital improvement program budget to the city council, the city manager in concert with parks and
recreation staff, shall notify the commission of:
1. Capital improvement program projects in said budget that are eligible for public arts, as defined in "eligible construction project" in section 7-15-2 of
this chapter. The funding source for each project shall be identified and the city manager shall indicate whether or not the funds can legally be used
to provide artworks at the project site and if the funds can legally be pooled with other monies in the public arts fund for use at a different site;
2. Proposed capital improvement program projects in said budget which are not appropriate for public arts, due to low anticipated public visibility or
public usage. The funding source for each project shall be identified and the city manager shall indicate if the funds can legally be pooled with other
monies in the public arts fund for use at a different site; and
3. Proposed additional or discretionary funds added to the public arts fund.
B. In conjunction with the approval of the city's annual capital improvement program budget, the city council shall consider the commission's
recommendations and may:
1. Determine that the funds for certain capital improvement program projects can be pooled, and therefore be deposited into the public arts fund;
2. Determine that the funds for certain capital improvement projects cannot legally be pooled and therefore cannot be deposited in the public arts fund;
3. Designate additional funds to be added to the public arts fund, and said additional funds may be utilized to place artworks in or outside existing
public buildings which do not otherwise qualify as eligible; the amount of said additional funds shall be discretionary; and
4. Designate more funds to the public arts fund, as it deems fit. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-6: APPROVAL:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 420/687
Contracts for development of artworks or for other purposes authorized by this chapter shall be in accordance with federal or state law and the city's
purchasing policies. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-7: OTHER AGENCIES:
If the city enters into an agreement with another public agency, whereby city monies are transferred to such agency for the purpose of performing a capital
improvement program project, which would otherwise be deemed an eligible construction project under this chapter, such agreement shall provide,
whenever it is lawful, that the recipient or its successor in interest shall take appropriate measures to ensure that monies are expended for development of
arts within this program. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-8: MANAGEMENT:
A. Public arts funds shall be appropriated and expended by the city council with the advice of the commission. The public arts program guidelines and
principles are hereby adopted to provide guidance in the appropriation and expenditures of the public arts fund and in accordance with this chapter.
These guidelines and principles may be amended only after a public hearing by the commission and adoption of a resolution by the city council.
B. The commission shall function in accordance with the adopted public arts program guidelines and policies and the ordinance establishing the
commission.
C. Once a project has been included in the approved public arts work plan, the commission shall be responsible for the selection of artists, the
commissioning of artworks, and the purchase of artworks. Projects recommended by the commission shall be presented to the city council for review
and approval at the mock up or maquette stage, prior to the fabrication and installation of the artworks. All contracts or purchases shall be in
accordance with the city's purchasing policies. Over time, the commission should aim to achieve an appropriate balance among local, regional, and
national artists in the public arts program. The enduring quality of the artworks should be a primary consideration during artist selection.
D. The commission shall require that all artworks needing operations or maintenance be reviewed by the appropriate city department staff prior to the
acquisition of that artwork. At least once every five (5) years, the commission shall be responsible for conducting a maintenance survey of the public
arts collection. This survey shall include a condition report on each artwork, prioritized recommendations for the restoration, repair, or maintenance of
artworks, and estimated costs. It shall be the responsibility of the various city departments to provide for the routine maintenance of artworks under
their jurisdiction. Such routine maintenance shall be in accordance with approved plans submitted by each project artist. The commission shall monitor
any nonroutine maintenance.
E. The commission may encourage and help obtain additional grants and gifts of public arts from outside sources.
F. Day to day management of the public arts program shall be provided by the city's parks and recreation department staff. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
7-15-9: PLACEMENT:
A. Artworks selected and implemented pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and any resolution thereto, may be placed in, on, or about eligible
construction projects. The artworks may be attached or detached, within or about such property, and may be either temporary or permanent. City
officials responsible for the design and construction of such projects shall make appropriate spaces available for the placement of artworks unless
prohibited by federal or state law.
B. Placement of artworks shall be followed, within a reasonable time frame, by interpretative plaques on or near the artwork, indicating the artist, the year
created and dedicated, and a description of the artwork or its reason for installation, as appropriate. Plaque placement shall be determined by the city's
parks and recreation department staff in consultation with the artist. (Ord. 1903, 1-24-2011)
Title 8
BUILDING REGULATIONS
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2340 - FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT . Go to new ordinance.
Chapter 1
BUILDING NUMBERING
8-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For use in this chapter, the following terms shall be defined:
OWNER: The owner of the principal building.
PRINCIPAL BUILDING: The main building on any lot or subdivision thereof. (Ord. 1999, 8-19-2013)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 421/687
8-1-2: OWNER REQUIREMENTS:
Every owner shall comply with the following numbering requirements:
A. Obtain Building Number: Owner shall obtain the assigned number to his principal building from the city addressing administrator.
B. Display Building Number: Owner shall place or cause to be installed and maintain on the principal building the assigned number in a conspicuous place
to the street in figures not less than two and one-fourth inches (21/4") in height and of a contrasting color with their background or in accordance with
adopted fire codes, whichever results in a larger and more prominent address display.
C. Failure To Comply: If an owner refuses to number a building as herein provided, or fails to do so for a period of thirty (30) days after being notified in
writing by the city to do so, the city may proceed to place the assigned number on the principal building and assess the costs against the property for
collection in the same manner as a property tax. (Ord. 1999, 8-19-2013)
8-1-3: BUILDING NUMBERING MAP:
The city addressing administrator shall be responsible for preparing and maintaining a building numbering map. (Ord. 1999, 8-19-2013)
Chapter 2
BUILDING CODES
ARTICLE A. BUILDING CODE
8-2A-1: ADOPTION OF BUILDING CODES:
This article shall consist of the 2015 edition of the International Building Code (IBC), and the 2015 edition of the International Residential Code, (IRC),
published by the International Code Council and together known commonly as the Building Code, with provisions that include electrical, mechanical,
plumbing, energy, and property maintenance requirements, and which volumes are incorporated herein by this reference as fully as though set forth herein
in their entirety, excepting only such portions as are hereinafter stated to be deleted therefrom; and such additional or amended provisions as are
hereinafter set forth.
This article, and all provisions incorporated herein by reference or otherwise, shall be known as the Building Code, may be cited as such, and will be
referred to herein as such and as "this Code". Further references made herein to chapters will be to chapters of the IBC or the IRC. References to section
numbers not proceeded by "8-2A" will be sections in the IBC or the IRC. (Ord. 2235, 7-10-2017)
8-2A-2: AMENDMENTS, ADDITIONS AND DELETIONS:
The remaining sections in this article represent amendments, additions and deletions to the requirements contained in the International Building Code
(IBC) or the International Residential Code (IRC), and where their requirements conflict with those of the IBC or the IRC, the requirements of this article
shall prevail. (Ord. 2235, 7-10-2017)
8-2A-3: SCOPE AND ADMINISTRATION:
Amend Section 101.1 of the IBC, Title, and R101.1 of the IRC, Title, by inserting the following jurisdiction name: City of West Des Moines.
Amend Section 101.2.1 of the IBC, and Section R102.5 of the IRC, Appendices, by adding the following:
The appendices may be utilized to determine basic guidelines or acceptable solutions towards meeting the intent of code requirements
(determination to be made by the Building Official).
Amend Section 101.4 of the IBC, Referenced Codes, and Section R102.4 of the IRC, Referenced Codes and Standards, by adding the following:
1. The provisions adopted by the Iowa Department of Public Safety, including but not limited to the current edition and amendments of the
International Energy Conservation Code, and the National Electrical Code, shall be considered part of the requirements of this code.
2. The current edition and amendments of the Plumbing Code, Mechanical Code and Fuel Gas Code provisions adopted by the Iowa Department of
Public Health, shall be considered part of the requirements of this code, with the following modification:
Corrugated Stainless Steel. Only CSST with an Arc Resistant Jacket or Covering System listed in accordance with ANSI LC-1 (Optional Section
5.16)/CSA 6.26-2016 shall be installed in accordance with the terms of its approval, the conditions of listing, the manufacturers instructions, and
this code including electrical bonding requirements. CSST shall not be used for through wall penetrations from the point of delivery of the gas
supply to the inside of the structure. CSST shall not be installed in locations where subject to physical damage unless protected in an approved
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=568 422/687
manner.
3. Administrative Policies established by the Building Official may be considered part of the requirements of this code to the extent that the provisions
are written documentation established to enable consistent enforcement of a code interpretation.
Amend Section 101.4.4 of the IBC, Property Maintenance, by adding the following:
1. The 2015 Edition of the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) shall be considered part of the requirements of this code to the extent
that the provisions are utilized as a mechanism to address property maintenance concerns and are not considered a mandate for enforcement action
on existing properties. If any provisions of the IPMC conflict with the amended provisions of this ordinance, the provisions of this ordinance shall
apply.
2. The Building Security provisions of the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) and Section 8-2A-25 of the City Code shall apply to new
residential rental projects. Documentation for compliance with these requirements shall be provided prior to project approval.
Amend Section 101.4.7 of the IBC, Existing Buildings, by deleting the existing language and replacing it with the following:
The provisions of the 2015 Edition of the International Existing Building Code (IEBC), upon submittal of the required documentation by a design
professional, may apply to matters governing the repair, alteration, change of occupancy, addition to and relocation of existing buildings.
In Section 103.1 of the IBC and Section R103.1 of the IRC, Creation of Enforcement Agency, Department of Building Safety shall mean Building Division
(a Division of Development Services).
(Ord. 2235, 7-10-2017)
8-2A-4: AUTHORITY TO INSPECT:
Amend Section 104.4 of the IBC and R104.4 of the IRC, Inspections, by adding the following provision:
Personnel currently employed by the City of West Des Moines and actively working in the Building Division as a Building Inspector, Plans Examiner,
Rental Inspector, Building Official, or any similar position as determined by the City, are hereby deemed as qualified, certified, licensed, or otherwise
authorized to review plans and permit application documents, and to perform all required inspections for commercial or residential projects, and to
perform rental housing inspections, and to perform any similar duties necessary to enable compliance with the adopted code provisions of the City,
and to fulfill the duties and responsibilities specifically listed in the job descriptions of said personnel.
(Ord. 2235, 7-10-2017)
8-2A-5: WOOD BURNING APPLIANCES (SOLID-FUEL-TYPE AND PELLET):
Amend Section 104.9 of the IBC, Approved Materials and Equipment, by adding the following provision:
New multifamily projects with stacked units (apartments, condominiums, and similar) shall not utilize wood burning fireplaces, stoves, and similar
solid fuel or pellet burning appliances that would require a chimney chase through the unit, or walls of the unit, located above. Top floor units with a
wood burning appliance located at the party wall of an adjoining unit shall have a minimum 2 hour fire resistive rated wall assembly at the party wall
location.
(Ord. 2235, 7-10-2017)
8-2A-6: WORK EXEMPT FROM PERMIT:
Amend Section 105.2 of the IBC and Section R105.2 of the IRC, Work Exempt From Permit, as follows:
1. No. 1 shall read as follows: One story detached accessory buildings used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the
floor area does not exceed 120 square feet and the structure does not utilize a permanent foundation.
2. Delete No. 2, Fences not over 7 feet high.
3. Delete No. 10 in the IBC: Shade cloth structures for nursery or agriculture purposes.
4. Delete No. 10 in the IRC: Decks not exceeding 200 square feet in area.
(Ord. 2235, 7-10-2017)
8-2A-7: EXPIRATION, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT (PROJECT PROGRESS/MAINTENANCE):
